Fingers crossed.In any case, Nasso will not be rejoining the work force anytime soon. The neuropathy in his legs, a direct result of the extensive chemotherapy, have disabled him. His once powerful arms and hands will need a lot of time and determination to recover. He has always been a physical guy and is ready and thankful to be able to get after it.Nasso is more than grateful for this Go Fund Me site. Our initial goal has been reached. But the future is still very uncertain for him. Up until now, Rancho Nicasio was able to cover his health insurance. He now has to rely on COBRA, which costs around $800 a month. Disability may help with his other living expenses for a while, but it’s just a situation nobody wants to be in.So I’m going to leave this site up for the immediate future and raise our goal.Your generosity has been exceptional. I’m reaching out to folks who may not have been aware or had the opportunity to contribute.

Our coach, teacher and friend Desi Herrera has recently been diagnosed with a glioblastoma brain tumor.  Fighting this horrible disease will require Desi and Freda to take time away from work as San Marcos Unified School District teachers. They must be able to focus on their three boys and the healing process without the pressure of the additional financial burden that accompanies this battle.Your support is needed and your contributions will help. Please consider donating to this amazing family.  No amount is too small and prayers are cherished.   With friends like you, and their amazing family, Desi and Freda have so much to fight for.  Thank you

I have started this page to raise money for my daughter Kendall's fight against Hodgkin's Lymphoma. She faced  this horrible disease 4 1/2 years ago and beat it, but on March 20th was given the heartbreaking news that it had returned. A lot has changed since Kendall's first battle with cancer. She got married, became a mother to my beautiful granddaughter, Sofia, and has continued her career. Kendall first noticed a lump under her arm about a month ago and immediately contacted her oncologist. He ordered a PET scan to check for any tumors she might have and also ordered a needle extraction biopsy. After the results of both tests were in, it was confirmed that the Hodgkin's Lymphoma was back.  She has a key lime sized tumor in her armpit, an orange sized tumor next to her heart and a small tumor under her collarbone. Kendall had a central line (port) surgically implanted in her chest on March 28th. This is how the chemo will be administered to her during treatment. Kendall will undergo 9 weeks of aggressive outpatient chemo in her hometown of Medford, Oregon starting next week. As soon as the chemo is complete she will undergo another PET scan to confirm that the chemo has killed the tumors. Next, Kendall will be moved to Portland, Oregon to get an even more aggressive chemo that will be given to her over 6 consecutive days. We were told she can expect the side effects from this treatment to be the harshest of anything she has faced to date, and will certainly cause her to lose her hair. Then the final and most brutal treatment will happen immediately after. The final treatment is a full bone marrow transplant that will remove all of Kendall's bone marrow, treat it with medication and her own stem cells and then return it to her body. This treatment will happen over a 4 week period and will put her white blood cell count at zero. Kendall's body will not have the ability to fight off even the weakest germs so this will be a very delicate time for her and our family. Kendall will be isolated from everyone except for her mother and I, who will care for her during the treatment and the 2 week recovery.  This will be a very rough time for her as she won't be able to have any contact with Sofia during this time.The funds we raise for her will be used to cover all of the outrageously expensive medical costs before, during and after her treatment that we already know her insurance won't cover. It will also be used for travel expenses to and from Portland, the 6 week housing for Kendall during the bone marrow transplant and recovery, and help with living expenses while Kendall is unable to work, which may be as long as 6 months. Kendall's husband Fily is working hard as a full time nursing student which makes it impossible for him to work at this time, so Kendall is the sole provider for her new family.For all of you that know me, this is the hardest thing I have ever had to do. I am a person that loves to give to others but at the same time find it so hard to ask for help, but this is an urgent situation. So from the bottom of my heart and on behalf of my entire family, I thank you for any support you can give.  Please share this link and continue to pray for my angel, Kendall Joy.

On April 13, our brother Kyle was diagnosed with stage IV glioblastoma, which is a type of brain cancer that is typically terminal. He had surgery on April 19 at Rush in Chicago to remove the main portion of the tumor. He is at home now, in Valparaiso, IN, recovering from surgery, but since the cancer is so aggressive, there is a long road ahead, which will include many chemo and radiation treatments that will begin over the next few weeks.All funds raised will be used solely for Kyle’s treatments, including the surgeries, doctors, chemo and radiation treatments and other medications.Everyone who has had the pleasure of knowing Kyle will tell you that he is hands down one of the kindest people they’ve ever met. Kyle is a smart, funny, quick-witted guy, who would do anything for those he loves. He has always had a strong love of nature and enjoys spending time hiking, skiing, rock climbing, playing frisbee golf, volley ball and many other sports. He also has an incredible passion for reading and connecting with others, whether playing lighthearted games or having profound conversations.Kyle is the kind of person who effortlessly forms deep bonds with those he meets, and he is adored by all who know him. Any monetary assistance you can provide (no amount is too small) to help ease this struggle for our brother would be greatly appreciated. Whether or not you are in a position to contribute financially, any and all prayers and positive thoughts are welcome.Thanks and love.

Dan and Colleen Codden are the parents of 2 beautiful girls Emma (10) and Ava (6) who live in Albany, NY.  Dan was recently diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL).  Although it's more common in children, Adult ALL is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow. This type of cancer can progress rapidly if it is not treated immediately.The course of treatment for ALL is aggressive and consuming.  Initial phases include inpatient chemotherapy, blood transfusions, radiation and antibiotics.  This disease is also prone to spread to the brain and spinal fluid, so weekly spinal taps are necessary to monitor conditions.  Finally, a bone marrow transplant may be recommended if the above treatment methods are not fully successful.  Dan and his family have a long road ahead of them.  It is expected that Dan will be out of work for a minimum of 6-8 months. As their family and friends, we want the absolute best care for Dan and we're reaching out for hope, prayers and for help. Through the generosity of our friends, family and strangers, any and all funds collected will be utilized to fund Dan’s care and the Codden’s living expenses over the next 6 months.  Any donation and prayer is a blessing and will very much be appreciated.  Please feel free to contact us through the campaign page for further information on how you can help.  Thank you.

A letter from Scott and Anne:Hi everyone!I’ve started writing and started over several times, but I’m realizing that no words will be adequate to express our appreciation for what everyone has done for me and my family. When my oncologist told us that our best hope is flying to Switzerland for treatment, we decided to say yes without knowing how we would pull it off. It almost reminds me of the “trust fall,” where you fall backwards and believe that someone will be back there to catch you. In this case, our family, friends and a lot of people who we don’t even know not only caught us, but lifted us up more than we can believe. The amount of funds raised in a matter of hours and days was stunning. I never would have believed that we’d have this kind of response, especially after many of you have already given to us in the past. It seems like every day on every television channel and every internet story, we are told how divided we are in this country for a variety of reasons. To me - this has been the ultimate reminder that people really are good. A large community that is united by compassion and kindness has lifted us up when we needed it the most. A community, by the way, made up of people in many states, several countries, men and women, straight and gay, Republicans and Democrats, young and old, etc. It will be impossible for us to ever thank this community of kindness in a way that feels like enough. But from the bottom of my heart, I appreciate what each one of you has done for us. Whether it was a donation, sending us a dinner, saying a prayer, giving a hug on a tough day, or just being a friend, this community has meant everything to us - and I thank you. We will do our very best to pay your kindness forward in as many ways as we can in the future.So here we are - in Switzerland. I will be admitted into the hospital tomorrow morning, and will stay until Thursday. I want this treatment to be successful for the obvious reasons, but I also feel some strange pressure to make all of your support worth it. I know that’s a little crazy, but I don’t want to let everyone down. Once I’m injected with the isotope, I will literally be radioactive. Nobody (including Anne) will be able to be around me for a day and a half. People experience a wide range of side effects, so I’m not sure what to expect. I’m both excited about the treatment and also already nervous about the future results. We will keep you posted on how it goes. Thanks again and I love you all!-ScottUPDATE:**Thanks to your generosity, we were able to meet our initial goal in less than a day!! Since the interest in helping has been so high, we will continue and any additional funds will go towards Scott’s second and third treatments that will come to a total of $36,000.  We are overwhelmed by the response and I know that Scott and Anne are as well. **Our brother Scott continues his courageous battle with cancer.  With his wife Anne and son Alec by his side, he has fought every day.  His best option for treatment at this point takes them to Switzerland.  We are hoping to raise enough to help him pay for his first treatment and anything additional will go toward subsequent treatments (he has to go 3 times).   We want them to be able to focus on getting the best treatment he can and enjoying every day without worrying about medical and traveling costs.  When we approached Scott about additional fundraising, he finally agreed but only if we would add a personal letter to you all.  We have attached the letter below.  Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.  As a family, we appreciate all your support.Renee & MichelleHi Friends and Family,First, we want to thank all of you who have offered to set up a fundraising site for us. We have agreed to let my sisters create one, but felt like we needed to tell everyone why. Since my diagnosis, we have gotten so much support.  People have set up fundraisers for us over the last few years.  There were times when we thought we had been given way too much and would eventually need to donate it to a non-profit.   However, this journey turned out to be more challenging (and more expensive) than we realized.    Our eyes are now wide-open to healthcare in America, and people with rare diseases are really in a tough spot. Luckily, we have you.  Trust me, without you all I might not be here today.  And if I were, we certainly would not still be living in our house or be able to send Alec to daycare.   We cannot thank everyone enough for all of the prayers and support.  We absolutely could not do it without you.   Up until now I have been able to see the best specialists in the country at MD Anderson in Texas and James Cancer Center in Ohio.  I have tried several clinical trials, but the cancer has continued to act very aggressively.   All of the specialists agree that my best chance now is a full body radiation procedure called PRRT.   It is an amazing treatment that can target all of the bone tumors in my body (I have many, many of them now).  It has been approved by the FDA for the more common types of neuroendocrine cancers, but not for mine.  Since insurance does not cover anything not approved by the FDA – we’re out of luck.  Believe it or not, it is less expensive to go to another country and pay out of pocket for the procedure than it is to get it here at the hospital in Pittsburgh without help from insurance.   We have made the decision to go to Basel, Switzerland to get the first round of PRRT.  The first treatment alone will be $12,000 (there are 3 treatments overall, 10 weeks apart), and there will obviously be significant travel expenses.  The cost is high, and it was not an easy decision for me, but I feel like no matter what happens, Alec has to know that I did everything that I possibly could to spend more time with him.  And besides, I haven’t given up yet. And I don’t plan on it.   We want you to know that you have already done your part.   Nobody should feel like they need to contribute again.  We love you all so much for everything that you have already done and nothing will change that.   We agreed to this because many are asking what else they can do, and honestly – we need some help.  Not counting the trip(s) overseas, the costs of endless appointments, prescriptions and travel add up quickly.  It has been very humbling to go from a life where we never had to worry about finances, to a place where we have to admit that we can’t do it on our own.  We can only say that your thoughts, prayers, kindness and support have meant everything to us and we’ll do everything that we can to pay it forward when we are able. Love,Scott, Anne & Alec

Meet the Smith Family. Jodi and Casey have been married for 17 years. The have 6 amazing kids. Hallie-15 Olivia-14 Luke-11 Lincoln-10 Emma-6 and Bo-3. This is no ordinary family. You can find the Smith’s constantly serving others, always having fun but most of all, they are always together. You will not find better kids or more devoted parents. In the fall of 2017, Jodi was diagnosed with stage 4 Ovarian Cancer. After months of difficult chemotherapy treatments and one major surgery, Jodi received a clean bill of health. A true miracle.About a week after her clean scans, Jodi packed up the kids and headed to Utah for a family-filled summer with the kiddos. Casey stayed home to work with plans to meet up with the family at a later date. A few days into the trip, Jodi received a phone call that Casey had collapsed and had two seizures while helping a friend move. Jodi caught a plane in the middle of the night to be by Casey’s side. Casey was diagnosed with Glioblastoma multiforme. An inoperable tumor in the brain. Casey will receive radiation and chemotherapy as treatment as this tumor does not yet have a cure.To know the Smith family is to love them. The Smith kids are incredible examples, faithful as can be and righteous in all they do. Plus, they are fun-loving, hilarious and love each other deeply. To say they’ve had more than their fair share is an understatement but they persevere and continue to choose the right. It is absolutely amazing how these kids have handled the cards that have been dealt to them with both of their parents being diagnosed with cancer. It’s a true testament of good values and a strong family unit.We’ve set up this account to hopefully provide some relief to their family at this time but also because so many people have asked to help. We are truly grateful for all the people who have rallied together and lifted this incredible family up by serving, sending texts, calling, helping with the kids, providing meals, serving others but most of all praying. We’ll continue to pray, pray, pray as we support the Smith’s and Casey.  #smithstrong

On Feb. 19, 2018, Chris went to the ER with severe stomach pain. 3 days before that, he had visited a doctor for a very benign procedure, however later that evening didn’t feel well. He chalked it up to the flu, since it was rampant around town. From the moment he arrived at the ER, his life took a turn that none of us could have ever imagined. Chris didn’t have the flu. Chris was septic. The procedure he had caused a Strep A infection in his blood that traveled throughout his entire body and all of the sudden he was fighting for his life. Chris experienced multiple organ failure, was intubated (on a ventilator), on dialysis and a team of doctors did all they could to save his life. The next few weeks in the Intensive Care Unit proved to be devastating. Chris went thru endless tests with rounds of doctors trying to stabilize his condition. After being intubated for over 2 weeks, doctors chose to perform a tracheotomy so that he could breathe without a tube in his voice box and to reduce the likelihood of infection.Chris had been through the ringer. His body had just barely survived multiple organ and acute heart failure. Then, he couldn’t move his arms or legs. Like many ICU patients who are that close to death, Chris was diagnosed with Critical Illness Neuropathy/Myopathy. This news was beyond anything we were expecting. The Neurologist said that in the 30 years he has been practicing he has never seen such a severe case. He said it may be months or years before Chris will be able to move again, from his neck down. He is not able to breathe on his own, nor able to speak. He is fed through a feeding tube to his stomach.The doctors announced on March 20th that the best course at this time to take would be to transfer Chris to a Long Term Care Facility and out of ICU, where he has now been for the past month. Chris may require professional care for a long time, perhaps the rest of his life.Chris and his wife own a wonderful CPA practice that they acquired after his wife’s step father passed away almost 2 years ago and they were gifted his business. This is their ONLY source of income. They have 2 little girls, ages, 1 ½ and 3 1/2. The financial burden on this family is overwhelming and they will not be able to take on all of the financial responsibilities alone.Our hope and prayer is for Chris to recover and one day regain mobility for independent living. Chris is well known by friends & family for his smile, charm and dedication to wife and children. His family gives heartfelt thanks for the love and kindness they have received to date. Please help support Chris in his time of need! This will help his family with medical expenses and rehabilitation.With love,His Family

Dear fellow friends of Kikkan,By now you’ve heard the news that Kikkan was diagnosed with breast cancer and is in Anchorage undergoing treatment.  Although Kikkan has insurance, not all of her associated medical costs are covered, requiring Kikkan and Jeff to face fairly significant out of pocket costs.   We’re looking to raise $45,000 to help offset the personal impact to Kikkan and her family and any funds that exceed their associated expenses will be donated to AKTIV against cancer. Your donation will go a long way in supporting her fight during a very difficult time. Thank you so much for your consideration.Friends of Kikkan

Please help support our dear friend Amy Mcbride-Howlett and her family of six (four children ages 4-13) by donating your money and prayers.  In 2013, at the age of 34, Amy was diagnosed with stage 3 glioblastoma, an aggressive form of brain cancer.  The family recently learned the news that it has returned and is terminal.  The doctors have given Amy very little time left and so we are reaching out to friends to raise money and support, to help ease the financial burden on her family.  It has been a very emotional 5 years for the Howlett family.  Prior to her diagnosis in 2013, Amy spent 10 weeks in the hospital hoping for a miracle for her babies, after experiencing premature labor.  Calvin and Harper were born, 12 weeks premature and spent 10 weeks in the NICU, until they were strong enough to breathe and eat on their own.  Finally, after 20 weeks of hospitalizations, the family of six, including her two older boys Noah and Carson, were re-united at their home. About a month later, Amy began to experience numbness/paralysis on her left side and face.  Amy went through a whirlwind of misdiagnoses and treatments, including MS treatments that led to a severe allergic reaction. Sadly, after biopsy confirmation, she was diagnosed with brain cancer.  In 2013-2014 Amy underwent months of chemotherapy, radiation and then eventually surgery to remove her original brain tumor and miraculously has been cancer free for the past 4 years.  Amy remained paralyzed on her left side from the original tumor but was otherwise able to lead a normal, happy life and mother her children as they have grown.  Sadly, about 9 months ago she started experiencing dizziness and a decline in speech and mobility that has continued to worsen and included a hospital stay in December for pneumonia.  Amy has been unable to speak and walk since August and the burden of care for herself and her four children has been on her family and, in particular, her amazing husband Sean.  We hope to raise funds to help pay for services, medical costs and other unexpected costs. Thank you for your prayers and support.

Those of us who are fortunate to know Blake Loebs know that he is a dedicated husband,  loving father, hardworking lawyer and a friend to anyone he meets. With his wife Alisa by his side, Blake enjoys watching and playing sports with his 7-year old son, Ryan. Ryan, a sensitive soul, shares his love of the Warriors and SF Giants with Blake and is 100% a daddy's boy. Blake's 5-year old daughter, Amanda, is the extrovert of the family. She an artist at heart and loves to perform her favorite dance moves for her family.In his professional life, Blake is a Principal with Meyers Nave.  He joined the firm in 2015 after serving 22 years as a Deputy City Attorney for the City and County of San Francisco.  Blake leads the firm’s statewide Peace Officer Defense/Civil Rights Practice. In 2013, the San Francisco Police Officers Association honored Blake as the “Citizen of the Year” and awarded him the Medal of Honor, the two highest honors that can be bestowed on civilians, reflecting his special expertise defending officer-involved shooting cases.Blake was recently diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. He is committed to fighting cancer with the same tenacity that he brings to fighting for his clients. He has a big fight ahead of him and needs to focus on this fight and not worry about financial matters. Sometimes people aren't sure how to help in times like this, but here is the answer: contribute any amount, no matter how small to help Blake and his family. We want Blake and Alisa to be free of financial worry so they can focus on his treatment and enjoying time together as a family. Together we can make a difference in helping out a dear friend who means so much to all of us. Thank you so much for your generosity!

It started with slight back pain and she didn't  think too much of it.   But as the pain substantially increased over the next couple weeks, Amy went to see a back specialist as she had a fast approaching trip to Morocco as the leader of a yoga retreat.  Just 2 days later she was admitted to Duke University Hospital with a diagnosis of Stage 4 pancreatic cancer. Described by her yoga family as "a strong presence embodying light, love and awakening.  Amy is a goddess whose light embraces all who are fortunate to cross her path. "  Her yoga classes in Raleigh create a safe space to practice many principles of yoga extending far beyond the physical asana.  Amy is married to my brother, her college sweetheart, Ian.  They met in 1996 at Myrtle Beach, SC while Ian was finishing his degree at Coastal Carolina University and Amy was enrolled in ECU.  Instead of migrating back north to Boston after graduation, Ian moved to Greenville, NC to be closer to Amy.  They settled in Raleigh, NC and share a love for friends, family, yoga, hockey, beer and of course their fur babies.  Amy and Ian's family, friends,  hockey and yoga family's outreach and support has been overwhelming and they are so appreciative.  All of the support is giving them the strength they need to fight this together.  Amy is fortunate to have some of the best cancer facilities in the country in their backyard.  She is starting aggressive chemotherapy at UNC/REX this week.  Together, Amy and Ian continue to fight and explore treatment options. Unfortunately, the cost of treatment is exorbitant and financially challenging especially on one income.  So many have expressed a desire to support Amy and Ian so I wanted to set up this page and hopefully alleviate some of the financial burdens of the mounting medical bills.

There are way too many amazing people who are battling cancer or who lost their battle with this horrible disease.  When cancer hits close to home affecting those you love and admire the passion to speak up for those affected most becomes too strong to settle for, “There’s nothing they can do.” Something, even if it’s one thing can always be done. Flavia Davis, a valued and loved nurse, wife and most importantly mother, has cared for so many adults and children over her extensive career.  Her exemplary work ethics and compassionate care made her instrumental in the initiation of nursing programs in Radiology and at Pediatric MRI and PACU.Then in 2016, Flavia was diagnosed with ovarian cancer.  This devastating news wrenched the hearts of all that know her, but Flavia remained resilient. She underwent several surgeries, radiation and chemotherapy, and suffered some severe complications where most would throw their hands up, but not Flavia.  She got on her road to recovery supported by her husband and young son. She was able to return to work doing what she loves and caring for those in need. After a routine checkup later that year, a small spot was discovered in her left lung and thus began another round of chemo.  Three months of treatment and things were looking hopeful. Even when the chemo was leaving her exhausted she pushed through caring for those at work and home. Then devastating news came end of June this year when she went in for her 3 month checkup. The tumor doubled in size and 5 additional tumors were found in her left lung. The cancer doctor said there is nothing they can do because it is so close to the mediastinum.  Flavia's battle with this very aggressive and rare form of cancer now has  her at risk of losing her medical benefits due to missing work to get the treatment she needs.  We think something can be done.  A prayer, a hope, your support in donating to help this beautiful soul so she can enjoy her husband and son as long as her destiny allows.  Every minute is more precious now, and it’s so sad that it takes news such as this to open your eyes to the wonder of life and the value of time.  So do something.  Let's not stop at words, She wouldn't!!!

On Friday July 13, 2018, Louie’s life, and so many others lives, changed forever.  While visiting North Carolina with friends to celebrate birthdays, go golfing and see their friend before his Wedding in October, Louie & a friend were in a horrific dune buggy accident.   Unfortunately, his friend did not survive.  By the grace of God, Louie survived and was found by one of his friends that is a nurse, after hearing his cries for help at the bottom of a cliff.  Louie sustained facial fractures, fractured vertebrae, broken ribs, collapsed lungs, bruising, gash in his head, amongst other injuries.  Louie just got his breathing tube removed today.  Doctors told his mother, Carol, that he has a long road of recovery ahead of him.  Carol is staying at a hotel and by Louie’s side.  At this point the family is unsure when they will be able to bring Louie home to continue his recovery and they need all the support we are able to give them.  Any amount helps. Please share! The family thanks you from the bottom of their hearts! #LouiesFight

Over 4 and a half years ago, my brother, Tripp, was diagnosed with leukemia. Not only did he have leukemia, but he learned at just 23 years old, that he had two types of leukemia; acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Since that day he has beaten all odds to be here with us today. He has had a bone marrow transplant, hip replacement, neurological issues and countless other trials. Any complication and side effect that could come from the transplant, chemo, medications, etc., it seemed like Tripp would fall victim. Today is no different. His current battle is due to Graft vs. Host Disease of the lungs.  Graft vs Host Disease (GVHD) of the lungs is caused by the new blood cells in his body, from the bone marrow transplant (the graft), attacking his lungs (the host).  GVHD can usually be controlled with different medicines, but in his case, the damage to his lungs was too severe before it was brought under control.   This caused irreparable damage to his lungs.  Despite many treatment plans, he is now at the point of requiring a double lung transplant.  Due to Tripp’s medical history caused by the leukemia and complications related to treating that disease, there are a limited number of facilities that would even consider him for transplant.  Duke University Hospital is the largest lung transplant program in the Southeast taking on more difficult cases like Tripp’s.  

Over 4 and half years ago, I saw my dad cry for the first time. I am starting this GoFundMe page to help four of the most important people in my life: my brother, my mother, my father, and my brother’s fiancé, Christine. In just a few weeks, my brother, mother (as his required caretaker), and Christine are temporarily relocating to Durham, North Carolina so Tripp can start the lung transplant program at Duke University Hospital. They will be in Durham for up to one year while Tripp receives and then heals from his lung transplant.  Although Tripp does have medical insurance, it doesn’t cover all the medical attention and therapy he will require pre-transplant and post-transplant. They will also have relocation, rent and living expenses for up to one year – none of which are covered by insurance.  This next year will be a very trying time for him, my mother, Christine and my father - as he will have to stay in Florida.

I am asking for your support to help my brother through this difficult time and to reduce the financial stress on my family. Any little bit helps, and we are beyond grateful for any generosity you are willing to give. In addition to any financial generosity, we ask for your prayers. God has already delivered Tripp through more complications than you could imagine. God is faithful and we are trusting in Him.

Support for Christopher Fatilua’s Recovery Greetings family, friends and anyone out there learning about Christopher’s story. My brother was injured in a life-altering accident on June 11, 2018. Chris was having a fun day of swimming when an unfortunate accident occurred that left him hospitalized with a serious spinal injury that has caused paralysis to both his hands and feet.My hope is that many will be moved to support Christopher’s recovery through donations or simply prayers for healing.Since the accident, Chris has been working diligently on his healing and is now ready to begin the intense physical rehabilitation needed for his road to recovery. Craig Hospital, a world-renowned spinal cord injury rehabilitation center located in Denver, Colorado, has accepted his referral and will require his immediate travel to begin his recovery plan.As one can imagine the cost for this type of treatment is extensive. As your heart is led to help my brother and our family, we thank you ahead of time for your heart-given financial support that will help Christopher and our family focus on his recovery as we ask God to continue His glory through Chris’ healing and path to recovery.I am reaching out on behalf of our family to ask you for your prayerful financial support for my brother’s journey. From the bottom of our hearts we thank you and love you.Blessings,Kailea Fatilua & Family

In June 2015 Andrew Tallon was diagnosed with Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM)--very aggressive brain cancer.  For nearly three years Andrew and his family have valiantly battled this illness and continue to do so with grace and fortitude that is unparalleled.  Andrew has endured multiple brain surgeries, innumerable trips to the City, and time away from family and work. For these reasons and because of the love we all share for Andrew, Marie and the boys we, the community of friends and colleagues, have started this gofundme page.  We hope to alleviate some of their financial burdens while expressing our concern and desire to help during this time of intense struggle.Thank you very much for joining us in this endeavor!

Providing an update on funeral arrangements for Kelly:The service starts at 10am but all are welcome at all times.Services will be tomorrow, August 8th, at the Church of the Madalene. Address:  3188 E 22nd St, Tulsa, OK 74114.Rosary and viewing will be at 9:00 AMMass of Christian Burial will start at 10:00 AMInterment will be at Memorial Park Cemetery followed by a luncheon back at the Church of Madalene.The slideshow presentation to remember and honor Kelly will be shown during the luncheon.All are welcome.In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Diocese of Tulsa and Eastern Oklahoma.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Update:  8-4-2018 5:00pWe were notified this afternoon that Kelly passed away peacefully in her home surrounded by her family.  Funeral arrangements are being made and will be shared shortly.  The family would like to thank everyone for their thoughts and prayers.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Update:  7-27-2018  10:00pGood evening, friends and family of Kelly, Brian and James,Due to complications in Kelly's condition, the doctors have released her to begin in-home hospice care.  She is resting peacefully and is pain free.  The family would like to send their sincerest gratitude for all of the calls, texts, prayers and donations they have received.  The outpouring of love and support has been overwhelming and they can’t thank everyone enough.  Please continue to pray for peace and strength during this very difficult time.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Dear friends and family of Kelly and Brian Balaskovits,As most of you know, on July 21, 2015, Kelly and Brian were confronted with some of the most frightening news anyone might hear. Kelly was diagnosed with Stage 3 breast cancer.  From the moment of her diagnosis, Kelly decided she would be a fighter.  The best example of this was in her initial Facebook post which read ... "Well my little family and I are embarking on a new journey together. I have stage 3 breast cancer. We have 100% faith in God, my amazing oncologist, our medical team plus tons of love and laughter to make it through this. Please try not feel sorry for us. I need support and strength, not sorrow. Please just keep my little family and I close to your hearts and in your prayers."Since Kelly's diagnosis in 2015, she has had multiple rounds of chemo and radiation, however the cancer has spread to her hips and femur.  Most recently, it has now metasticized to her liver. In just the last few weeks, Kelly was laid off from her job and no longer has medical or life insurance.  Kelly and Brian are now traveling back and forth to Houston's MD Anderson for treatment.As recently as the week of July 16, 2018, Kelly began having pain in her abdomen and was admitted into St. Francis Hospital in Tulsa, OK.So many people have reached out to ask how they can help.  First and foremost, the Balaskovits family needs your prayers.  They are strong in their faith and while they are in the fight of their lives, they believe in God's will and His ability to rid her body of this awful disease.Next, between the trips to Houston, the hospital stays, the medications, chemo, radiation and everything in between, the last thing they should have to worry about is money.  As you can imagine, Kelly and Brian aren't the type to ask for help, so as their close friends, we are going to ask for help on their behalf.We are asking for you to take a moment, say a prayer, and then donate to this awesome family.  Any amount is the right amount.  No donation is too small or too large.  Last but not least, share this with everyone that knows this family and even those that don't.Thank you so much for your thoughts, your prayers, and for your donation.  It means the world to Kelly and Brian to know how much each of you care for them and how willing you are to help them in this time of need.

Dan is extremely optimistic and will not let this get him down. He has a way of reaching his students and inspiring them to be better, work harder, and always give back. He has earned so much respect and now it is our time to give back. Please consider donating to help them with upcoming expenses by attending the 5K run/walk , contribute directly through this GoFundMe, or mail your donation directly to the established Benefit Funds (listed below). Main St. – P.O. Box 330St Henry, Ohio 45883Or Dan Thobe BenefitOsgood State Bank275 W. Main St. – P.O. Box 69Osgood, Ohio 45351

Rollinsford Officer Shawn DePasquale was diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer which has spread to his liver.  He received the news in January just a couple weeks after graduating from the NH Police Standards and Training Academy.  He has been receiving chemotherapy treatments at  Wentworth Douglas Hospital and in July an operation will be performed to remove the tumor and he will undergo additional treatments.Since Shawn is a new hire, his sick and vacation time is quite limited so the members of the department decided to help him financially.  He is only 25 years old and lives in Dover with his fiance'The members of the Rollinsford Police Department have decided to grow facial hair (normally not allowed) as a fundraiser for Shawn.  The staff will be allowed to grow a beard from Memorial Day to Labor Day as long as they receive contributions for Shawn.Any and all donations no matter how small will be greatly appreciated.

I am Sam Karam, a dad, a husband, a brother, and a friend. I'm in the biggest, scariest battle of my life, and I need your prayers, your positivity, and your help. ￼ 

Back Story 

I had been having chest and back pain for quite a while. In October 2017, I was admitted to the hospital and tests showed a mass in my right lung. 

A biopsy in November showed it was benign. Since it wasn't cancer and surgery to remove it would mean months out of work, we decided to try to shrink the mass with medication. Unfortunately, the pain didn't get better. As the months went by, it got worse and worse. It got to the point where I couldn't sleep and I was coughing up blood. 

In June of this year, I went to St. Luke's emergency room and was admitted for many, many tests. My pet scan showed "activity" in two different areas of my lung, plus a muscle under my ribcage. Alarmingly, the original mass had grown a great deal in a short time. Doctors performed multiple biopsies. 

Diagnosis 

On July 9, my wife and I were given news that shocked us to our core: I have cancer. Spindle cell sarcoma, a rare form of cancer that affects bone, muscle, and connective tissue. Sarcoma is difficult to treat under the best of circumstances, but when it has spread like mine has, the prognosis is much worse. 

Treatment 

Conventional doctors are recommending chemotherapy to try to shrink the largest mass before removing it and a large portion of my right lung, and then possibly radiation. All of these treatments are expensive and painful. Worse, their success rate against cancer like mine is low. 

A Safer Alternative

I have researched and found a clinic in Mexico that has successfully treated sarcoma using nutritional therapy and other treatments, such as: 
*Oxygen therapy 
*Rife therapy 
*Biomagnetic therapy 
*Regenerative cell therapy 
*Low-dose chemotherapy 
*Hyperthermia 

Costs 

A 3-week treatment plan at the clinic costs $22,000. However, difficult cases may take 6 weeks or longer to treat. In addition, I won't be able to work during that time. Since I'm self-employed, I won't be getting sick pay or vacation pay, and I'll still have all of the usual household expenses to pay. 

What Your Donation Is Doing (8/21/18)

I have already stayed the initial 3 weeks ($22,000), plus an extra week ($7,300). I was unexpectedly hospitalized for a week (versus the usual outpatient care), which was an additional $2,800. After learning that one of the tumors had grown, we decided to fight it with stem cell/bone marrow treatment, which costs $3,500. Now we are seeing signs that my tumor is dying, but it looks like I will need at least one more week of treatment ($7,300).

How You Can Help 

My journey with this disease has just begun, but with the grace of God and your generosity, I'm determined to beat it. Please donate whatever you can. I understand times are tough for a lot of people, but even $5 will help me get the treatment that can save my life. I'm grateful for every penny. Please help me see my daughters reach adulthood. Help me see my 4 children get married. Help me one day see my grandchildren. 

Help me fight. Help me live. Please share my link  with your family and friends:  https://www.gofundme.com/SamFightsCancer Feel free to post it to Facebook or Twitter. 

I appreciate your prayers, your kindness, and your donations. 

Questions? 

Have any questions about my condition or treatment plan? Please leave a comment and we'll be sure to respond. From the bottom of our hearts... THANK YOU AND MAY GOD BLESS YOU! ￼

MOVING MOUNTAINS FOR MOANA!Everyone asks what they can do to help and this is our chance...... This is how we can help MOVE MOUNTAINS FOR MOANA! If you know her, you love her! She’s the friend you wish you could spend more time with because she always makes you feel so good about yourself. She's kind, she's gracious, she’s one in a million!!! Moana will be traveling to California to Stanford to get the best treatment possible for this rare type of cancer called Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma. She will do radiation every day M-F and chemotherapy once a week. Treatment begins on July 2nd and will last about 7 weeks.  Let’s help her by taking away the financial burden so that they can focus on their young family and what’s most important like getting Mo better. WE LOVE YOU MOANA!! We are praying for you and hope we can do this small thing to help you kick cancer to the curb! xoxo Jenne-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------If you haven't heard what's going on please read the following below. This was written by her husband Brian and he has graciously allowed me to share it.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Moana has had normal allergy type symptoms for several years. She lost her hearing several months ago and eventually was not able to breath out of one of her nostrils. We figured that it was some type of a chronic sinus infection. After receiving antibiotics and it didn't improve Moana's provider sent her in to get a CT scan. After the results came back they asked her to do a biopsy. When the results came back we found out that she has NPC. It is a rare form of cancer here in the United States but is more common in other countries and seem to show up a lot in people that are Chinese. The Dr. put a tube in her ear and now she can hear but still can't breath out of her nostril. But she is so positive that she has been celebrating her hearing returning. We found a few places across the US that perform surgery to remove these tumors. We decided that Stanford would be the right fit for Moana. Once we sent in all of the imaging, we found out that she was not a candidate for surgery because the tumor was too big. However, after going through the process we felt like Stanford was still the right place for her to receive chemotherapy and radiation. We will be meeting with the specialists that will be doing her chemotherapy and radiation next week and will have a much more clear understanding of how long the treatments will last. Based on other patients and estimates, it will most likely be roughly six weeks of radiation everyday Mon-Fri but I'm not sure yet how often and when she will receive the chemotherapy treatments. Stanford will be a little far from home and it isn't the most convenient place to get in and out of but after the research that we did we felt like it was the right place. Logistically, we will figure out how it is all going to come together. Moana has been very upbeat and positive and is really an inspiration to me. She has taken the news well but I know that she is a little scared. The love and support that we have received has been life changing. It completely changes the way that I look at the world. Brian England

Three weeks ago, our family got the kind of phone call that everyone dreads. My three-year-old niece was being rushed to the hospital by ambulance. She had suddenly lost control of the entire right side of her body and could not stand on her own. While my terrified sister and brother-in-law, Megan and Rob, rushed with Indigo Rose to the hospital, the rest of us paced by the phone, anxious for news. Indigo had always been healthy, so we were hopeful that nothing could be seriously wrong.When Megan called, however, the news was bad. Indigo had had a stroke, and the doctors didn't know why. For days, she had to undergo test after test, from bloodwork to EEGs to MRIs and MRAs. She had another stroke two days later, where she was paralyzed on one side of her body again. She had to have so many tests that the doctors had to insert a PICC line that goes from the veins in her arm to her heart to make blood draws and medicine easier to administer.After a few more days, the doctors had some answers for us. They diagnosed Indigo with Moyamoya, which is a rare, progressive cerebrovascular disorder. She is at Stage 4, whereas other children diagnosed at her age are generally Stage 1 or 2. Moyamoya causes the  arteries at the base of her brain grow narrower and narrower over time, leading to strokes, muscular weakness, seizures, and, without medical intervention, death. The pediatric neurosurgeons at UCLA recommended bilateral revascularization surgery, which bypasses her blocked arteries,  as the only way to  save Indigo's life.Last week, Indigo underwent the surgery. While the plan was to work on both sides of her brain, the neurosurgeons realized mid-surgery that Indigo's brain was hemorrhaging, and so she was too weak to have the operation on both sides. They spent 6 hours working on the left side of her brain, and they will have to repeat the surgery on the right side of her brain in another 6 months. She woke up from the surgery in extreme pain, and her little face was swollen and bruised.Although the surgery was nerve-wracking for everyone, especially Megan and Rob, we thought that maybe the worst was over. It wasn't. During the night after the surgery, Indigo suffered another stroke. The following night, she started having seizures, one of which lasted more than three hours. That seizure caused Indigo to again lose all her mobility, and also took away her ability to speak.From the time this nightmare began until today, Indigo has had 5 strokes, and 16 seizures.She can't move or talk the way she used to,  and she is scared and bewildered by what is happening to her. She suffers from night terrors, hallucinations from her anti-seizure medications, vomiting, and overwhelming exhaustion. Her little body has been through so much. Megan and Rob cannot bear to leave her side. They are in agony watching their little one suffer as she is. Her life is hanging in the balance.Indigo has been hospitalized in the ICU for nearly a month now.  As a result of this medical catastrophe, their medical bills are piling up. Current estimates put Indigo's medical bills in the hundreds of thousands of dollars. They need as much help as they can get to help Indigo get well enough to go home, and then to return to the ICU for the second half of her surgery. This beautiful, strong, sweet little girl has been through so much, and she is fighting so hard to live and thrive. Please help as much as you can.

We are going to close out the account on Friday. Thank you again for the overwhelming support, it has been amazing. Please keep Jeremiah and the kids in your prayers. —————————————————————We are very grateful for everyone’s extreme generosity and support. The money raised has been an unexpected blessing to Jeremiah and the kids. Please continue to keep them in your prayers. Service Info: Visitation and memorial service will be held at St. Paul’s United Methodist Church in Port Republic on Wednesday March 14th . Visitation from 11:00-12:00 and service at 12:00.————————————————————-UPDATE: Late Wednesday night, Colleen went to be with the lord. Please continue to pray for the family. The outpouring of love, support, and prayers have been overwhelming and we are soo grateful. Thank you all!————————————————————Unfortunately, Colleen has been diagnosed with a rare terminal cancer.  She is currently in NYC, at Cornell Hospital.Colleen is the loving mother to five amazing children ranging in age from 14-3. She also homeschools all of the children. ￼￼￼Her husband Jeremiah has been with her every step of the way, however this means he is missing work. We are attempting to raise money for Jeremiah to be able to take the necessary time off of work and get the kids started into the Pilgrim  Academy. Thank you for for your continued support and prayers through this difficult time.

Dear Friends & Family of Jacquie Marumoto,As most of you know, a little over a year ago in February of 2017 Jacquie suffered a massive, debilitating hemorrhagic stroke. Those early days and weeks were very medically challenging and it was unclear how or IF Jacquie would ultimately recover. After 6 arduous weeks of fighting for her life in the Yale Neurological Intensive Care Unit, Jacquie was transitioned to Gaylord Rehabilitation for 4 months of intensive therapies where she made significant progress towards gaining independence: improvement in swallowing, feeding, speech therapy etc.. Following this challenging therapeutic rehab experience she was discharged to a rehab center in Fairfield. Jacquie returned home eight months ago. While she has continued to progress, recovery is slower and it is unclear how complete the recovery will be. She is still in a wheelchair and fully dependent on her husband, Larry, sister in-law, Jill, family from California, and many other care providers. Life at home has it’s own set of challenges from the vantage point of a wheelchair: narrow interior doorways, lack of a wheelchair accessible ramp for entering & exiting the home, and limited access to the kitchen only to name a few.Before her stroke Jacquie had an 11 year career with Oracle most recently serving as Senior Director in the health sciences group. She took a very active role in raising their daughter, Avery now 10. Accompanying Avery to her activities, birthday events, and school commitments was something Jacquie always took pride in doing. She enjoyed Yoga classes and was an avid golfer. In short, she was like all of us: multidimensional and enjoying a full work, family, and recreational life.Recently Jacquie was admitted into an outpatient program in Norwalk. However, upon starting the out-patient program her home health aide support was cut off. Now, Larry and young Avery must be responsible for attending to all her daily living needs. This understandably has resulted in an inability for Larry to resume full employment, which in turn has amplified the healthcare cost burden on the family. A prideful man, Larry has resisted overtures for financial help for many months. He chose to draw down the family's savings rather than ask for help. Unfortunately, the costs have now become overwhelming. Jacquie’s projected healthcare costs for the next two years are projected to be over $100k - Insurance, deductibles, therapy equipment, home modifications needed for wheelchair accessibility ….. the list of financial demands is nearly endless !We are fortunate to live in an affluent community, and most of us are lucky enough to have successful careers. Until two years ago, Jacquie and Larry were as fortunate as we are. It is sobering and sad to realize how quickly this can be lost, and how precarious our seemingly stable lives can actually be.While Jacquie has made significant progress and now is, in very general terms, able to:-- speak -- though volume, word recall, and breath control are still issues-- walk using a walker with assistance-- sit upright and maintain balance with some prompting-- transfer from a wheelchair to bed and more with assistance-- accomplish most ADLs (activities of daily living) at a wheelchair level with minimal assistancePlease join us in our goal to ease their burden. We are starting this “Go Fund Me” page in an effort to raise  $100K to help support our friends in need. With our help, Jacquie can continue to progress with her rehab and her home can be made more comfortable and accessible. Our small contributions will go a long way, and Jacquie (and Larry) will be eternally grateful for your generosity of spirit.With love & gratitude, Team JacquieCindy Reejhsinghani, Jill Perlstein, & Sabrina Maurer

Billy "Salvi" Woods was diagnosed with Systemic Scleroderma in August 2017 and has been out of work and on oxygen 24/7 since his diagnosis.Scleroderma, an auto immune disease, has compromised his lungs and he's looking at a bi-lateral lung transplant at Mass General Hospital. He is currently in the evaluation process to determine whether or not he is a viable candidate for the transplant surgery. Salvi has been out of work since August and only receiving a portion of his normal paycheck.  We are asking family, friends, co-workers to assist in raising funds to help defer medical bills.On behalf of Billy's immediate and extended family, we thank you from the bottom of our hearts!LETS RALLY!SALV-STRONG!

Do you know Ty Hawkins? Everyone knows Ty and what a heathy, strong, determined and giving person he is. Always willing to help anyone and everyone and donating most of his time to his family or to coaching and mentoring the youth in the local area. To most of us he is known simply as “Coach Ty” and he now needs your help! On August 10, 2018 Ty was admitted to the hospital and days later he had unexpected open-heart surgery to repair several aorta and valve issues that were not functioning properly. While no complications and a full recovery were expected, he has experienced several unforeseen challenges and obstacles in his recovery. While his heart surgery was successful, and his heart is getting stronger every day, he continues to be challenged with fluid and collapsed lungs and blood clots. While he remains sedated through this tough time he is now being transported by helicopter to another hospital in central Florida that specializes in the type of recovery he needs right now. Ty’s recovery is going to be very long and difficult, but we all know what a fighter he is and know that if anyone can pull through this it is him. His family has been at his side since the surgery praying for a healthy and speedy recovery. But now this relocation to a central Florida hospital is really taking its toll on his family. To remain vigilant and support his recovery, they now need to temporarily relocate to be at his side. As with any unexpected event support by family is a definite. In addition to prayers we would like to ask for support for their family as well. As we all know, Ty would be the first one in line to support any family and all causes for anyone. His family now needs your help! Please help by spreading the word about Ty and asking for prayers and donations on his behalf. This GoFundME page was setup for his family to assist in his recovery and expenses. We will continue to provide updates on his recovery and continue to pray for a safe and speedy recovery.

Kesta is a young smart girl from Haiti who has severe complications in her lower body specifically her excretory system which was totally destroyed due to an accident.  Unfortunately, Kesta was trapped in between two buses that collide as she was making her way home. She miraculously survives after more than 5  surgical procedures which help reconstruct her bladder. Several Doctors who came to her hospital, Bernard Meus, noticed more complications and need her to have a  more complex surgery that will help her recover and lower her intake on some drugs like morphine that are injected in her body at least 4 times a day. This drug is the only one in her environment that can relieve her from pain. It is very addictive and such surgical procedure can truly help. Unfortunately, it is impossible to do such complex and high-risk procedure in Haiti. That's the reason we need any help possible to get her to either Florida or Cuba where there is more equipment for this surgical operation. She needs every penny, every dime, every dollar you can afford to donate. She only asks for a future and we can make it happen. Let us be kind and compassionate.Mon_Cash:  3159_1740I'm Melissa Pierre, the GoFundme's campaign organizer, Kesta and I knew each other in Haiti where I am from.  I am currently living in Tampa. I'm friend with Kesta Jerome and her mom, Rose Conceptia Paul.  Students from SFA and I had to help them in such difficult moment, that's why we took the decision to make this campaign.Kathleen Dessources Pierre-Louis, former President of the AACFA, Association des Anciennes de Saint Francois d'Assise, is friend with Rose Conceptia Paul and Kesta Jerome. For some safety reasons, she will be the one in charge of the finances for the campaign. We want to thank her for her precious help.

The beloved McKeever family is facing challenging times right now as their son Zachary has been diagnosed with cancer. We are asking those who can to help support them through this difficult time by contributing funds  to be used for extra medical expenses. Any additional funds donated will be used to support other families dealing with childhood cancer. Thank you in advance for your generous support.

John is a wonderful young Christian man who is one of the hardest working individuals I have ever met. He has been diagnosed with a rare  cancer that will need expert physicians and hopes to go to MD Anderson for treatment immediately. John is a strong man and has deep faith in God but this battle will be costly and John is the sole source of income for his family. Your help and contribution in John through this fight would be very greatly appreciated. In addition, if you could kindly spread this message and link to others that may know John it would be a wonderful way to increase the chances of reaching as many caring people as possible. God Bless You All

Me, Glenn Lundy and Shawn Hayes are heading up this Go Fund Me for Michelle Marie Sri and Chad Morgan. Michelle was recently diagnosed with stage 3 breast cancer. Michelle has 3 boys and has a battle ahead. Being self employed insurance is a challenge. Michelle has a long road ahead with lots of out of pocket testing and large deductibles. We are asking for 24 hours of prayer and donations to help a member of our auto family.

Reena Leah bat Chana Fradel was diagnosed with stage 3 triple negative breast cancer while 34 weeks pregnant with her first child. After many treatments it had spread and had become a stage 4.  Our beloved Reena has sadly passed away on 5/21/18 and has left behind a loving husband and amazing 15 month old son. Throughout this excruciating painful journey, Reena and Shimon had to deal with a very emotionally and financially draining time period. Reena has fought so bravely from the moment she was diagnosed. A beautiful neshama she is-that has brightened so many people’s lives. Let’s show Shimon and son Natan our love and support in this tragic time, to ease the financial burden so they can focus on mourning, healing, and being together.

URGENT Update: The original story that was posted is still below but we need to share some of the most recent changes to Kaitlyn's treatment plan. Due to recommendations from her doctor at the center, she is going to be receiving a low dose chemo treatment twice a week. This is not a traditional form of chemo and it is administered with insulin. The side-affects are minimal and the results have been very promising with other recipients. However, it is very expensive, well over the cost of the initial treatment plan. Each treatment is $5000 and her treatment calls for 2 infusions per week. In addition to the new cost of treatment, we're looking at an extended stay in California.  We have exhausted every financial avenue available to us and  without your generosity our funds will run out before the end of this week. That is how urgent this request is. We appreciate everything that you have all already given and we humbly ask you to continue to give what you can. Please share with everyone that you can and ask them to share it as well. Hi, We’re Tim and Kaitlyn Yant.. Thanks for taking a few minutes to read our story. We first met when we were just kids in our church youth group but started dating when we ended up going to the same college years later. We got married in November of 2009. We finished school, got real adult jobs, and bought our first house. Everything a young couple usually does. Five years after getting married we decided to start trying to have babies. After years of trying doctors diagnosed Kaitlyn with uterine fibroids but said there didn’t seem to be any other complications other than the fibroids. But, there definitely was... On May 12, 2017 we went out to dinner with Kaitlyn’s family - a normal family dinner on a Friday night. After getting home that evening Kaitlyn began experiencing a lot of stomach pain. After being in pain all night we decided to head to the emergency room on Saturday May 13th. Expecting it to be a common gall bladder issue or something like that, we couldn’t have ever prepared ourselves for the news we were going to get... A CT scan revealed a very large malignant mass in Kaitlyn’s uterus. Kaitlyn was diagnosed with stage IV ovarian cancer, low grade serous carcinoma. A punch to the gut. Our world stopped spinning as every plan for our future came crashing down around us. We broke the life altering news to our families that Mother’s Day weekend 2017. Then began the whirlwind of doctors appointments and treatments. Kaitlyn endured surgery after surgery and unsuccessful treatments. We were told that she would have a maximum of 1 year to live. Kaitlyn’s oncologist said that the cancer she has does not usually respond to chemo so if we wanted to pursue having traditional chemo treatments there is a very high chance that it would not work or if it did work, then the chance of the cancer coming back a few years later and being more aggressive is extremely high. BUT, the fight is NOT over yet. Kaitlyn has beat the odds and is now living day by day past the one year original prognosis. Because of the grim outcome of traditional treatments we have chosen for Kaitlyn to seek non-traditional treatments at Cancer Center for Healing in Irvine, CA where they have seen success in stopping and reversing cancer! Cancer has stolen a lot from us - Our ability to have children, our money, and our time. But it can’t take the things that truly matter - our joy, our faith, and our hope. Please warrior on with us in prayer as we cry out for Kaitlyn’s complete healing. Also, please consider donating to help pay for the numerous medical bills, medical supplies, and further treatments that Kaitlyn needs.

We all know at least one person who has had cancer in our lives, whether we have had a personal battle, or helped a loved one with cancer. Our friend Keren was diagnosed with Stage 2 breast cancer, and it has been heartbreaking to watch. Besides the physical trauma and emotional toll, cancer has been an enormous financial burden for Keren's family of 6. There are numerous appointments, 6 months of chemotherapy, extended recovery times, and bills piling up. As of now, they are unable to afford the full 6 months of chemo. Between Keren and her husband, Boaz, their combined income allows them to keep their family together financially. However, without her contribution to the family income, they are already facing some very serious challenges, especially with 4 children. This is a big obstacle for the family, and it is something we don't want Keren to worry about on her healing journey. I am asking for your help and support during this time for the Zuzan family. We want to see Keren cancer free and heal without the stress of not being able to financially afford treatment. Please help keep this family whole, and help this family. They have the biggest hearts and need your love and support during this time! Please consider donating, no amount is too small and the gesture will mean the world. When we are faced in tribulations, it is the love and support that gives us the hope and courage to push through. All donations will go towards treatment and remission. We appreciate your support and prayers, and thank you from the bottom of our hearts!*Beneficiary for this account with be Boaz Zuzan, Husband of Keren Zuzan. Boaz and Keren are friends of mine, and Boaz will be able to give funds to Keren.

Hello friends, family, and loved ones,Recently Genaro Lombera was diagnosed with Primary spinal glioblastoma multiforme (cancer) that is extremely rare and accounts for only 1.5% of all spinal cord tumors. Therefore, its treatment is still ill defined. Genaro has always been a hardworking man and provider for his family. He is the sole provider for his family of six. The landscaping company he’s built from the ground up is proof of how much hard work and determination goes into everything he does. With the onset of this disease Genaro has been stripped of his ability to work and provide for his family or pay for the treatment he needs to get well. He has started chemotherapy and radiation, but is currently bed ridden as the tumor cause immobility. We are asking for any donations to help pay for his surgeries, treatment and rehabilitation while he and his family go through this tragic time. Thank you all for your love support, and prayer.Elibeth Pereda-Barragan - Genaro's Wife

The woman that lights up a room the moment she walks in. The mom who is raising the most stylish and independent daughters. The spin instructor that inspires others to live their best lives. The person who dances like no one is watching when everyone is watching. The friend who makes you laugh until you can't breathe. The woman who loves life fiercely. If you know Lianne, you know she is all of this and more. Last month, Lianne was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer. She will begin treatment in the next few weeks. Lianne and her family have a long road ahead of them. Any amount of money to alleviate the stress of medical bills will have an immense impact.We are asking the community to show up for Lianne the same way she shows up for us every day: with an open heart and unwavering positivity.

Matthew James CorpsteinJuly 29th, 2018Where to begin to tell this miracle story of Matthew’s? I feel like I could write an entire book. This has been a long difficult road filled with many sad tears, happy tears, big decisions, and everything in between. I’ll stick with a short version for now and write the entire story at another time. During our 20 week ultrasound, which led to several others and a MRI quickly following, the doctors discovered that our baby was missing most of his/her brain. And instead of a brain, it was replaced with cerebral spinal fluid. The fluid was going to continue to expand the head of our baby. The head size was measuring about 3 weeks ahead of normal. We were told our baby wouldn’t live past several days, if not hours, or die before birth. The diagnosis given was semilobar holoprosencephaly, and the prognosis for these cases are very bleak. Essentially since half way through our pregnancy, we have been preparing to bury our precious little one, and spend as much time as possible with him or her as we could. While still pregnant, we tried to do as many memory-making things along the way like: baby’s first motorcycle ride, baby’s first vacation, and other fun things to fill our hearts with happiness instead of focusing purely on the sadness that would inevitably come. Speeding this story up to week 37 with our last ultrasound on Friday, July 27 our perinatologist looked at the ultrasound and said that if we wanted any chance of a normal birth without c-section, we needed to get induced immediately. Baby’s head size has grown to 4-5 weeks ahead of schedule. We were admitted to Mercy without issue within a couple hours and began the birth and induction process. After 2 full days of induction with nothing like our birth plan (more of that story to come later), we gave birth to Matthew James Corpstein at 11:21am, 7 pounds 14 oz, 21 inches. He was breathing and regulated his heartbeat on his own. We were told that these were things he would do, but the doctors weren’t sure he would be able to feed. We were told he likely wouldn’t see, hear, or feel pain. After he was born, he was able to latch and nurse right away. He responded to lights, voices, and touch. These were things that he supposedly wouldn’t do. We decided to do a follow up MRI to determine if the original diagnosis was right. The results came back, and then suddenly we were talking with a pediatric neurosurgeon who said that he definitely DOES NOT have semilobar holoprosencephaly. That there is much more brain tissue than originally thought, and instead he has hydrocephalus. This new diagnosis still means Matthew has extra fluid in his brain, but the difference is that the fluid is pushing the brain tissue to the side of the head, making it appear as if there’s no tissue, when in fact there is. The new MRI showed that they could see all or almost all of the front and right brain tissues, and most of the back side. The left side was difficult to tell because that area had the most fluid that was pushing into all the other sides of his brain. The neurosurgeon told us it’s possible he could lead a completely normal life. Many hydrocephalus babies live with no abnormalities. Many also have some developmental delays or disabilities. We simply couldn’t believe what we were hearing! We had prepared for the last 4 to 5 months of not bringing a baby home, of using hospice and end of life care, and now suddenly Matthew’s chances of survival are high and having a fully functioning life could be possible! It’s like buying a lottery ticket and actually winning the jackpot! We were overjoyed, and I just still can’t put into words how we feel about the amazing news. We know God was protecting us and our beautiful baby boy, and we had put our faith in His hands, come whatever may. So where are we now with all of this?Matthew needed to do emergency brain surgery to drain the fluid from his brain, which would allow his brain tissues to expand back. The surgery happened when he was just two days old, on Tuesday, July 31. This required putting a shunt in his brain, that would drain down into his abdomen. He will have this for the rest of his life, and likely will have other surgeries, tests, and MRIs down the road to make sure it is functioning properly as he grows. Surgery went well, and he is recovering like a champ. The neurology nurses told us this was a very severe case of hydrocephalus, but he is doing remarkably well. A good friend called him Matthew The Great for being such a miracle, and that’s exactly what he is. He is our little miracle. A boy who wasn’t supposed to be born alive, much less do anything else, has showed us that God is protecting us and blessing us beyond anything we can imagine. Matthew means "Gift from God"!We ask for prayers and well wishes during Matthew’s initial healing and what the future holds. Thank you from the bottoms of our hearts for those of you who are praying, sending messages, and donating money.

column3: Our friend Scott Uchida needs help
column9: Hi friends! Our friend Scott Uchida needs our help. Scott has been going through some issues for a while, and after undergoing medical care we now know the severity of his medical/physical/emotional condition. A lot of you have reached out and wondered what is going on. Scott has been a wonderful friend to all of us, from taking people to their favorite  shows, taking photographs of them, and showing you the best places to have ramen in LA. Scott has been in the music industry for a long time, and sadly will be unable to continue working as a full time photographer. He’s a friend, Father, and Grandpa. We all want him to get as healthy as he can, and recover to his best abilities. Recently, Scott has admitted to very concerned friends that he had used a heavy recreational drug for an extended period of time this year. Through a meeting with his daughter Kassy and friends, they convinced him that his health was a major concern and the drug usage was possibly causing behavioral and physical problems. While hospitalized, they found that his heart was severely thickened, causing heart failure which he will have to be monitored closely and take medication for the rest of his life. Neurologically he has suffered multiple strokes that have affected his entire brain. There are certain parts that will no longer function properly, causing severe behavioral changes and some physical ones. The damage is permanent and irreversible. He will be going to physical therapy, cognitive therapy, and speech therapy to rewire the brain. He will also be going to a rehab center for drug usage when medically better. Currently this is what we know, and these are the conditions he has been diagnosed with: Leukoencephalopathy Intracranial atherosclerosisHypertrophic cardiomyopathyScott is in the care of his Daughter Kassy, his Mother, his sister Coleen, and his brothers. Kassy is handling all his finances, and will be handling all donations for payments for treatment. Kassy has a little boy and is a full time Mom so to not overwhelm her, If you have any questions feel free to email me. Thank you, - Mariah Lynch

column3: A Helping Hand for John Pruitt
column9: John Pruitt is one of the world’s greatest men. He is an incredible band director, a friend to all, a mentor to countless students, a devoted family man and a loyal follower of Christ. In January of 2018, John was told due to a  heredity condition, he would need heart surgery. It didn’t seem fair to any of us because John is an incredibly healthy person. However, he chose to follow his doctor’s advice and have the surgery. Within three days of his surgery, and while still in recovery at the hospital, we were told that John had three massive strokes. He was airlifted to another hospital in Charlotte and after a procedure to stop the strokes, was put in the neurological ICU. When he first started to wake up, John was paralyzed on the entire right side of his body. He couldn’t speak, eat, stand, sit up, or even keep his eyes open for longer than a few seconds. Since then, almost 4 months has passed. John has made incredible progress that seemed impossible by many doctors. He has full physical function of his body. He is actually very physically fit considering what he has gone through. Cognitively though, he still has a long road ahead of him. We have discovered through an incredible amount of research, that there is a facility that can help John with his specific needs in Atlanta. His doctors do not think there is any other facility that can help him in the way that he desperately needs. Insurance will not help John pay for the rehabilitation in Atlanta. As a family, we have decided we have to help him get there regardless. We are now at a point that we have exhausted all financial means possible. We are so greatful for the hundreds of people who have already helped John with donations, food, cards, gifts, and keeping his house maintained. We are asking now that anyone out there who knows John personally or through the grapevine, to please donate what you can to his cause.  The rate for care at the facility in Atlanta is over $1000 per day. With an average length of stay of 90 - 120 days we would ultimately need to sell John's home to cover the expense. We are desperately trying to keep his life waiting for him exactly as he left it but we also know we have to get him back first. Any and all help you can give is greatly appreciated by all of us. If you can’t give financially, please add John in your thoughts and prayers. His army of prayer warriors has gotten him through countless hurdles already. Now he just needs to get through a few more. Thank you!-The Pruitt Family #wearehereforyoupapajohn

Help Jennifer Beat Leukemia!In late March 2018, after a trip to the Emergency Room with abdominal pain, it was discovered that Jennifer Mullen Golden’s white blood count was very low. She was diagnosed with Acute Leukemia (ALL).Treatment and RecoveryJennifer’s course of care is chemotherapy, radiation, and an upcoming bone marrow transplant, all the while being admitted to Memorial Sloan Kettering in New York City. Her treatment is anticipated to span over 100 days with a recovery period from 18 months to 2 years. Throughout this time her husband and family have been juggling caring for her three young daughters, aged 5 through 14.Where your donation will goAlthough medical insurance should cover much of the cost of Jennifer’s care, it is anticipated that there will be limits to coverage which might present some expensive bills. Financial burdens should not be an obstacle on the road to recovery. Some of the funds raised will assist her children to maintain participation in school and sporting events. Donations would also help pay for transportation and parking to and from the hospital, as well as assist with normal expenses due to the loss of wages during this time.How you can helpJennifer’s loved ones, friends and neighbors have been a blessing to her family, and she knows that she is not alone in this fight! Please share this with friends and family and keep Jennifer in your prayers. If you can make a donation, no matter how big or small, it would be very much appreciated for the tough times that lay ahead.Let’s help Jennifer beat this!
