My name is John Prince and I am the father of Jordan Prince.  Jordan is 26 years old and has been in the grip of anorexia and bulimia for the last 10 years.  During the last 12 months, Jordan has been hospitalized 4 times.  Last summer, she was in the ICU for almost 8 weeks and she is currently in OSF.My daughter is almost dead and the beautiful daughter that I once had is gone.  I spent the last 2 years full of anger.  Anger at my daughter for what I viewed as the terrible choices she continued to make each day and anger that I could not find a way to control the circumstances.   The Lord has brought me to a place of peace and I just want to take care of my little girl.My wife and I reached out to Selah House in Indiana and they have agreed to help.  OSF sent Jordan's file to them yesterday and they called my wife today.  They stated that our daughter is in a severe state and will die without immediate treatment. My daughter is unable to keep a job and currently has Illinois Public Aid as her health insurance.  There is not a single treatment facility that accepts IPA.  Selah House has agreed to cut the daily rate to $850.00.  At first, I thought this sounded like an unusually high amount, but after talking to other facilities, we found out that this was a highly discounted rate.  (Denver Acute is $5500.00 per day)Per Selah House's advice, we are currently trying to have the hospital keep Jordan until a bed opens up at Selah House the last week of March.  Selah stated that Jordan would need to be there 12 weeks.  As I type this, there is a little box out to the side giving me suggestions on what to write.  It says to "Tell how these funds will help you or your love one".It will help me by keeping my daughter alive and helping her to have a quality of life that I have not been able to give her.  I want to help her to the depths of my soul, but my business went under at the end of 2017 and I am at the end of myself.  It would help my daughter to continue to live and become the person I know she can be.Not knowing what else to do or who to turn to, I am doing this GoFundMe page.  I need to raise $71,400.00 before a bed becomes available at the end of this month.  I will be forever thankful for any help you might be able to offer.

Please join us in showing our love and support for Steve and his family in their greatest hour of need. Below are words shared from his wife, Sarah Pupillo. Dear friends, I’m writing to ask you to pray for my sweet husband. On Wednesday night he had a seizure. We came to the ER via ambulance where it was discovered that he has a mass in his brain. He was admitted to the Neuro ICU and over the next several days they did more testing which found two more smaller masses in his brain and one in his left leg. Tomorrow morning he will undergo a surgical biopsy (under anesthesia) to determine what kind of cancer this is. I can hardly believe I’m typing these words. Our lives have felt like a horrible dream that we need to wake up from. We are frightened and anxious and overwhelmed. BUT, we are resting in God’s promises. This was no surprise to Him. He loves Steve and He is holding him right now, guiding him through this difficult journey. So many of you are praying hard for us right now and have asked your friends and families to pray too. From the bottom of our hearts, thank you! Please, please keep praying for healing, for peace, for strength and courage. Even in moments of fear, we feel God’s overwhelming peace and we are so thankful for that.Zephaniah 3:17  -  "The Lord your God is in your midst, a mighty one who will save; he will rejoice over you with gladness; he will quiet you by his love; he will exult over you with loud singing."

Early last week, our dear friend, Michelle was diagnosed with stage 3 peritoneal cancer - a rare type of cancer that affects a very small percentage of the population. She was admitted to St. Anthony's hospital, in St. Pete, Florida,  on June 7, and has spent the days since surrounded by an incredible group of supportive friends and family who continue to be amazing advocates for her care. Michelle's symptoms began just a few weeks ago, but progressed quickly. After consulting with her primary care physician, she underwent a CT scan hoping it would reveal the cause of her abdominal pain and bloating. The CT scan did show some abnormalities, but additional testing was required which took her to St. Anthony's. We received official word that cancer cells were present in her abdomen on June 12, and surgery was performed the same day to remove as much of the cancer as possible. Doctors were pleased with the outcome of the surgery, and to no one's surprise Michelle was an absolute Rockstar from pre-op, through the entirety of the 4-hour surgery, into post-op and recovery. We look forward to getting her back on her feet as soon as possible so she can take the next step in her treatment plan, which will involve chemotherapy. As we begin to digest this news and plan for Michelle's continued care, we have decided to create a GoFundMe page on her behalf as an outlet for friends near and far to connect and contribute should they feel called to do so. As you can imagine, the emotional shock of a cancer diagnosis and so many uncertainties are only compounded by the financial stress.First and foremost, your love, prayers and emotional support will be the family's lifeline in the months to come. The outpouring of support already has been such a blessing and provided great comfort to Michelle and her family. Michelle's beautiful, kind and caring spirit for others has touched so many people in so many ways over her 56 years on God’s earth. As a nurse she has spent her life caring for others, and now it’s time we care for her. We hope that we can raise $25,000 to help defray some of the medical costs and and household expenses while she is unable to work, easing the family's financial burden, and allowing her to focus on beating cancer!We believe that God is bigger than the cancer that has impacted her, and everything is possible through Him. So, Michelle will fight, and we will fight with her. Thank you for being in our corner!

Lenny Torres was driving in Pennsylvania on a business trip on Friday March 2nd, when a tree fell on his car. Lenny suffered a severe head injury, fractured vertabrae in his neck, a bruised heart, and both ankles were shattered along with other cuts and bruises from the incident. Lenny was transported to the University of Maryland Hospital Shock & Trauma Center in Baltimore, Maryland. During surgery on his face, the doctors were unable to save Lenny's right eye. Lenny still needs to undergo facial reconstruction surgery and ankle surgery. Right now Lenny is sedated and in stabile condition. Lenny's wife, Mariana and youngest daughter drove through the night on Friday from Greenville, SC to Baltimore to be with him while he is in the hospital. Local families in Baltimore have graciously opened their homes for a time to give Mariana a place to stay while doctors continue to do procedures and get Lenny to a place where he is able to travel. Once Lenny is able to be transported back to Greenville, the plan is to bring Lenny home to heal and continue treatments.As you know, there are and will be travel expenses, food, and an unknown amount of medical bills that are going to start piling up as a result of this incident, not to mention Lenny is unable to work right now. At this time, it is unknown how long it will be before Lenny can make the trip back to Greenville or what kind of rehabilitation he will have to go through. We don't know if worker's compensation is going to assist in the incident at this time, so let's get the ball rolling by helping this sweet family financially in the meantime. Galatians 6:2 "Bear one another's burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ."

Julie's story begins in the summer of 2014 when she was diagnosed with Stage-3 breast cancer.  She endured months of chemotherapy, a double-mastectomy, radiation and later reconstructive surgery.  Throughout the difficult journey, Julie remained strong & focused on beating her cancer, which she had named "Oscar"; as in the Grouchy Green Trash Can Monster from Sesame Street.  She has always had a passion for children and loved her job working with the children at Little Lambs Preschool.  The children truly loved Miss Julie as well. During and after her treatment, she made her experience a way to support other women with breast cancer by offering them support, guidance and resources.  Just one week prior to her stroke, Julie was again offering such support when she provided help and guidance to a gentlemen she had just met who was suffering with cancer.  Her family and friends supported her all along the way and some even participated in a Bee Brave 5K Run/Walk, in October 2014, raising funds for breast cancer research.  In spring 2015, with great celebration, Julie was declared cancer-free!!  She had beaten Oscar!!  To celebrate her victory, Julie and her husband Chuck took a trip to Hawaii and looked forward to a bright and healthy future.Fast forward to early 2018, Julie started experiencing shortness of breath and a CT scan revealed fluid around her lungs and that she had a slight enlarged heart. The following day an echo cardiogram was completed on her heart, which reveled damage to one of the valves showing it was operating at only 20%. This damage was caused by the chemotherapy (known as Cardio Toxicity). The following day during a needle biopsy (Thoracentesis) of the fluid, on March 1st, Julie suffered a stroke.  She was rushed from Spectrum Pennock Hospital in Hastings to Spectrum Butterworth Hospital ER, in Grand Rapids, where we received the sad news that she had suffered severe brain damage in her left brain resulting in right-side paralysis, speech and cognitive issues. Julie spent 16 days in the Critical Care Unit, then transferred to the stroke unit where she spent two additional days, before being transferred to Spectrum Rehab Facility. Julie then began a long, difficult journey of rehab. She has repeatedly revealed her strength and spirit by enduring a ventilator, grueling tests, painful treatments and challenging physical therapy on a daily basis. The past months have been a virtual roller-coaster due to her heart issue, spasticity in her right leg and foot, as well as multiple other complications, setbacks and difficulty finding the proper balance of medications.  Along the way, medical insurance issues have made getting her treatment needs difficult. She has been through approximately 2 weeks of rehabilitation at Spectrum Rehab Facility, then 4 weeks of rehabilitation at Mary Free Bed in Grand Rapids, back home for in-home therapy for a few weeks, then, because of setbacks for various reasons, has been in and out of the hospital, as well as another almost 2 weeks of rehab at Mary Free Bed (not covered by insurance). Chuck has been working tirelessly day and night with God's grace and doing a marvelous job of advocating for her and doing what's best for her; which is what one would want done for themselves if they could not speak the words.  Julie's team of doctors are finding that their options are becoming limited given the condition of her heart and the effects of the stroke.  In the meantime, Julie will be at home trying to get her heart strengthened with medication.  She will need round-the-clock care, as well as daily professional in-home care, which will not be covered by insurance, contributing to the financial strain that has been building over these past months. The costs have been significant and will continue to be.  Those who know Julie know that her big heart has compelled her to always be there for anyone in need and the Lord has blessed so many people through her support and actions.  She has always had a unique ability to know what people need even when they did not know they needed it themselves.  She goes above and beyond to provide whatever is needed.  Be it a helping hand, resources or sometimes just her love and prayers.  At this time of need, here is our opportunity for 'Giving Back to Julie'.  Her family is so grateful for all of the support: thoughts, prayers and expressions of love that she has received.  It is with great faith that we continue on to whatever God has in store. OCTOBER 2014 - BEE BRAVE 5K RUN/WALK

Erin is a loving daughter, sister,  wife, mother, friend and educator. She has been part of the the Worth Elementary School family as a reading specialist since 2003. In October 2016, she was diagnosed with Stage 3 Triple Negative Breast Cancer, which is an aggressive form of breast cancer that occurs in younger women and has a high rate of recurrence. After undergoing chemotherapy and radiation, her scans came back clean this past December. Erin thought she had finally beat this awful disease. A month ago, her cancer returned and had metastasized to her brain, lungs, liver, and bones. After receiving this difficult news, Erin and her family maintained their hope and were ready to fight this again. Immediately upon this diagnosis, Erin began treatment with radiation and chemo. Unfortunately, this treatment has put too much stress on her body, but her strength continues to amaze us every day.  We will maintain our hope that she will be able to come home soon! If you are lucky enough to know Erin, you know that she truly is a special person. She has an undeniable love for her husband, Adam, and their two beautiful children, Brooklyn (6) and Connor (4). Her parents, Diane and Mike, and her brother, Ryan, along with amazing extended family have been constant supports for her throughout this difficult journey.Erin has always been someone to put her family and others first. It’s time for us to put her first and help her with her fight. This page has been set up by her friends to help offset expenses for Erin’s cancer treatments and to alleviate financial stresses on her husband and two young children. As long-time friends of Erin and her husband, Adam, we have set up this Go Fund Me page to help with any medical expenses or unexpected financial situations that may arise during this difficult time. We humbly ask for your help. No donation is too small. #mottsgotthis

Philecia was diagnosed with Stage 4 Breast Cancer and this is her story: “In April 2017, I found a small marble sized lump in my left breast while adjusting myself in my sports bra. I did not qualify for insurance, nor did I have the financial means to afford private insurance. I had to go to the free clinic, where they referred me to an imaging center. The test results showed a benign cyst. In retrospect, they think the cancer was behind it, not seen on the ultrasound at that time. They told me to come back if it bothered me, otherwise the cyst did not alarm them/seemed normal. In November I started to notice it was larger and actually noticeable through clothing, which bothered me a little. I said I would get it checked out, but holidays happened and life got in the way, and they said it was benign.... Come January 2018 I was snowboarding when I fell and hit my chest pretty hard. Two weeks later it wasn't getting better and seemed swollen, so I went back to the free clinic where they ordered an ultrasound. That came back abnormal. I then had a second ultra sound, blood work, and referral for a mammogram which showed a more serious issue. I then had 4 biopsies, two left breast, 1 lymph node in left armpit and a pretty traumatic one on my right breast. The results are that I have ductal carcinoma in situ. As I waited for the next steps they started doing an MRI, and a petscan, which resulted in showing the cancer has spread to both my lungs and my sternum. Our protocols for women and breast cancer testing is not good enough. It is not  protocol to get a mammogram until 40 years old because programs/insurance won't pay for it without valid reasoning. Mind you because I didn't have insurance, didn't qualify, and am not able to afford private insurance and the clinics are so full and over worked I was forced to wait 5 months to know what was going on. Had regulations and insurance been different I wouldn't be in such a fight right now."Those are the words of our friend Philecia. Her cancer is stage four and has spread. She is the strongest most vibrant woman we know. We are gearing up to fight this as hard as we can as a team, which is why we need as much help and support from our respective communities as we can get. There will be more tests, more surgeries, special necessities, and specialists. Once we’ve beaten this, the testing will be ongoing and extensive to ensure it never returns. Even if you are unable to help Philecia financially please share this far and wide, help us help our beautiful friend. To follow her journey, through the good and the difficult, Instagram updates will be posted @philecia

If you know Amy Gross, you know that she loves her family with all her heart, cares deeply for her students, and moves through life with positivity and joy.  She has been teaching since 1987.  She has impacted thousands of students with her infectious love of life.  Amy was recently diagnosed with stage 4 lung cancer that has metastasized to her liver.  This came as a huge shock because Amy has lived a very healthy life style and has never smoked.   Recently Amy has begun chemotherapy and is also seeking alternative treatments to support her immune system through the process.Unfortunately, the alternative treatments are not covered through her insurance.  We ask that you prayerful and thoughtfully consider joining us in supporting Amy and her family by donating to help offset this huge financial burden.  Amy has always been one who has rallied around others.  This is our chance to rally around her!#HopeforAmy #proudtobeMUSD #honorthecode #sierraproud

column3: Help Laura, Chad, and Kaylee Jane
column9: Unfortunately, our beloved friend and coworker Laura Thompson suffered unimaginable complications during the birth of her beautiful daughter Kaylee Jane, and has been fighting for her life for the last several days. Thankfully, Kaylee Jane is just as healthy as she is beautiful. Both Laura, Chad and many of their own family members have been a part of our Worley family for years now and they need our support. While we would all love to be by their side to lend our support, most of us are left wondering what we can do to help. All of our positive thoughts and prayers are being heard - Laura knows that Kaylee Jane and her family are counting on her, and rooting for her, and she knows how much love and support she has from all of her extended family. If you have the means to contribute monetarily, please do. We know there will be mountains of bills to pay following Laura's hospital stay, all of the expenses that come along with a new baby, and of course the lost wages as a result of all of this. Let's remind this family how much they mean to all of us. Thank you all in advance for sharing this with the hundreds of folks who love and care for Laura and Chad, and who can't wait to meet Kaylee Jane.

Dear friends, As some of you know, Collin experienced a small but significant stroke on the night of Saturday June 30. Friends who were with him got him to the emergency room at Jefferson General Hospital in Port Townsend quickly. His body, smile, motor functions are improving. The most affected area is his speech center. He is filling in the gaps, is surrendered to his situation, but is operating at about 25% comprehension and memory. He has to rebuild his language, and is getting his ideas across with a lot of help in translation. He will be doing a lot of speech therapy. His uncanny resilience will serve him well.Collin has a great support system in Port Townsend. He has a very close and supportive family as well.While Collin is recovering we can support him emotionally and financially.  He will not be able to work for at least 9-12 months. As we all know, he is a kind soul who in his generosity and brilliance has cared for so many of us. He has been a friend, a coach, an educator, a mentor, a person who we all look up to. With your help we can give him time to heal and get back to work.Please contribute to this fund for him to get by while he recovers. Please be as generous as you can. Please share this info and campaign with others who may not know of this yet. Your generosity will be deeply appreciated by Collin.Thank you very much,Michael Cohen (on behalf of Collin)

As many of us have learned, our dear friend, colleague, advisor, and confidante has been handed a pretty heavy cancer diagnosis this past week. Chris mentioned that his kids, Madeline and Oliver, might need rides to/from their summer jobs this year. Let's do better than this; let's join together to get those Wenzler kids a car. They need to get to their summer jobs, of course, but they also might be called upon to run errands and help their dad (and mom) in any way possible. I read somewhere "there is no such thing as other peoples' children." So, Maddie and Oliver, we all LOVE YOU because we truly love YOUR DAD. As you already know, he is the best of the best. As Chris and Melissa and Madeline and Oliver have served so many of us with friendship and joy, let us dig deep and offer a little help today. Whether you have been touched by Chris' life at John Carroll or through his many connections in Cleveland, we know Chris' first loves are his wife, Melissa, and Madeline and Oliver. Along with our prayers of faith and healing, let's give from our pockets, too.All money donated will obviously go to the Wenzlers! We can get this going, and when Chris is all healed and all bills are paid, they can take a vacation with the leftover funds! I am a former colleague of Chris' from John Carroll. I live in Hudson, Ohio. I am simply a friend who recognized a need to help, and knew we'd all support Chris and the Wenzlers with an established platform. The funds will be spent on a car for the Wenzler kids and any medical and other expenses incurred by the family during Chris' treatments and recovery. Chris and Melissa Wenzler will have sole access to the account.

In July, 2017, our friend, step-dancer Kieran Jordan got sick with a “flu” that never went away. Symptoms included debilitating fatigue and body aches, night sweats and insomnia, low blood sugars, nausea and low appetite, tingling, twitching, shooting pains, anxiety and palpitations.In April, after seeing eight doctors and many holistic therapists, she was diagnosed with Lyme Disease. Like many people with Lyme, Kieran was never aware of the tick bite and never had the classic circular rash. Lyme is often missed or misdiagnosed because the symptoms can be vast and can look like many other illnesses. Late-detection can make the disease more difficult to treat and heal. Kieran is now seeing a Lyme-literate nurse practitioner and receiving antibiotic treatment. Her visits, specialized lab tests, and treatment are not covered by insurance. This comes after nine months of illness and distress, which have forced her to give up much of the work she loves — teaching jobs, performances, and more.Kieran and her husband Vincent are both self-employed and an illness like this brings overwhelming financial stress. They have made incredible contributions to our flourishing Boston music/dance/art scene and it is times like THESE when we, as a community, are able to give back and help ease the burden. Funds raised will go directly towards recouping out-of-pocket medical costs and lost income, and for continuing expenses including non-covered doctors’ visits, lab tests, and supportive therapies for Lyme Disease treatment.

Matt, Melissa & Dylan are heading to Pittsburg to hopefully get some answers for their precious baby. Dylan has been diagnosed with Krabbe Disease and we need a miracle. Pray for peace, healing, and mercy. “So do not fear, for I am with you; do not be dismayed for I am your God. I will strengthen you and help you; I will uphold you with my righteous right hand. Isaiah 41:10”Matt and Melissa will not be able to work... they will be spending all their time with Dylan in the coming months.

Help my father, Mayer Balser, be near his family for the remaining time he has left.One month ago, our father fell ill from stage 4 brain cancer known as, Glioblastoma. He had surgery in Boston Hospital to remove the cancerous tumors however, it was unsuccessful. Tumors removed during surgery have since grown back and doubled in size, in just two weeks. Our father is currently in Memorial Sloan Kettering hospital in NYC. He does not have much time left. We would like to move him into hospicare near our home in New Jersey, so that we can spend as much time together in his last few weeks.Please open your hearts and help us bring my father closer to home by supporting our fund for medical bills and transportation. Anything counts. We thank you in advance for your support.With love from the Balser family!Edit: these funds will fully extend into the other various medical bills that we have in this situation, thank you all for helping

Daniel Weber is a loving father to 2 beautiful, energetic sons, Mason and Carson and husband to Ticinie (Heller).  He has worked in the oilfield for most of his adult years, making a living for him and his family in the oilpatch in North Dakota.  Dan is a man you can take at face value, a no BS kinda guy.  He is family driven, hard-working and honest...a one of a kind guy anyone would love to know and have in their corner.  If you needed his help, he would lend a hand at the drop of a hat  He has a sense of humor like none other, one of his best attributes by far.  On the morning of August 24th, 2018, Dan was involved in a tragic accident on the farm.  He was life flighted to Trinity Hospital in Minot, ND, where he was rushed into emergency surgery.  He suffered broken ribs, a broken sternum, broken shoulder, broken hip, and a broken vertebrae in his upper back.   His L1 vertebrate shattered into his spinal column, squishing his spinal nerve, which has caused him to be paralyzed from the waist down.  After the first surgery and X-rays, they also found that he had blood in his stem cord, which would affect his paralysis more, and also that he had a broken femur.  He then had a 2nd surgery, the same night, to put pins in his hips to keep them stabilized.  He will also need a complete hip replacement, but this will happen at a later date. Dan will have to endure more surgeries to repair all that has been damaged, including an IVC filter in his hip, which will be permanent.  He is one tough cookie and has been pushing everyday to regain movement in his lower extremities.  He has some limited feeling and movement in his left leg above the ankle, below the knee.  He also has some tingling in his  left arm, which could be caused from nerve damage.  Dan has a long road ahead of him and will eventually be transferred to a rehab facility at a later date.  Dan is a tough guy, maybe a bit stubborn, like we all know, but is keeping positive thoughts through what could be the most trying time in his life.  With all of his family and friends continuing  to send up their prayers, we know Daniel will overcome this obstacle.  He has already shown he's a fighter in these first few, trying days.  He has also stated that he WILL be walking by the end of the year!  Now if that isn't determination and positivity, I don't know what is!Ticinie is continuing to give updates daily on Facebook with what is happening and how he is progressing.  Dan's future as of right now is uncertain when it comes to work and his job.  If you are able to donate to this wonderful family to help defray everyday costs and medical bills while the family is supporting Daniel during his recovery, it would be greatly and lovingly appreciated!  We will also be setting up a benefit for Dan and his family at a later date. Thank you and God Bless!

The Lakota West High School Football Team is raising funds for their classmate and teammate, Matt Stratman, and his family to help with medical costs associated with Matt's recent hospitalization. On Saturday, June 9, Matt was playing in the Lakota West Alumni Lacrosse game, when he collapsed as he exited the field.  After being rushed to Children's Hospital of Cincinnati, Matt was diagnosed with an AVM (arteriovenous malformation) and is currently in a coma.  All donations collected through this effort will be sent directly to the Stratman Family. Thank you in advance for your support! Sincerely, Ladonnis & Teammates

Dear Mission Viejo Country Club Members, Friends and Family,It is with a heavy heart that we must break the sad news that our beloved co-worker and friend, Irene Yelvington has been diagnosed with a very rare form of breast cancer. Irene has been part of MVCC family for over 22 years and has served in many capacities at the Club, including her current role as our Catering Director.  Irene has been married to her husband Jerry for 21 years and they share two beautiful children, Jake who is 12 years old and Evalyn who is 6 years old.Irene will begin her chemo treatments on March 19th, and they are expected to last up to 4 months. After treatments she will then face surgeries to remove the tumors. Irene most likely will not be working during this time and will require help financially as she fights this battle of her life. Irene and her family will most likely start incurring costs related to her medical needs, such as insurance deductables, specialized medications, child care expenses and other related costs. It is our goal to help relieve most of the financial burdens for Irene and her family ensuring she focuses only on fighting this battle. We are asking for any donations, small or large, everything makes a difference!! May God Bless Irene and her family during these difficult times...

column3: Help Erika Zak Get a New Liver
column9: Erika, our dear friend and sister, urgently needs a liver transplant to save her life. Now we can help Erika and her family, Scott and Loie, get to the Cleveland Clinic and pay for travel and accommodations, related medical expenses and recovery. In 2014, Erika was diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer that had spread to her liver. Her daughter, Loie, was just 3 months old. She underwent more than 70 rounds of chemotherapy and several surgeries. Then came a major blow, followed by a miracle. One of the procedures left her liver severely injured, and it began to fail. But Erika also began taking an immunotherapy drug that her doctors say has killed most, if not all, of her remaining cancer. She was officially listed on the transplant waiting list last week, and will be heading to Cleveland very soon to wait for a liver. For the first time, Erika has a real opportunity to see her sweet daughter grow up. And we can help. We have seen our friend and sister fighting so hard for this. We have seen such strong support from her family and friends, and what a happy home she has made for Loie. It's been a heartbreaking and awe-inspiring struggle, and they are so grateful for all of your support. Read the CNN story about Erika here.

ANGEL'S FAMILY IS BEING DEVASTATED Angel is a security guard who greets visitors entering the Philadelphia Museum of Art. As people come up the Rocky steps and enter the Museum, the first smiling face they see is Angel’s. He’s incurably positive and funny, disarming visitors with his warmth and helpful suggestions — just the person you’d want to encounter when entering a foreboding stone edifice. The Museum places Angel at that key spot because he is so accomplished at what he does, and he is highly valued for it. But Angel’s beaming smile hides just how much trauma he’s enduring inside. It turns out his slim build is supporting a Herculean weight, one he often doesn’t want to talk about. Angel and his wife Jacqueline have a beautiful family that includes their son Angel Luis, 33, and daughter Nitza Jeannet, 30. Angel Luis is married and has an 8-year-old son, Angel Luis Jr. Nitza has a 11-year-old daughter, Mia Lovey, as you can see from their family photos.When Angel met Jacqueline, she was a recent widow. Her husband, ironically also named Angel, had died at the age of 33 from a brain tumor. She had two young children, and Angel enveloped his new family with such love, becoming their strength as they started their lives together. Their kids grew up and started families of their own, just as it’s supposed to be. But a few years ago, Nitza began having internal pains, and she didn’t know what was causing them. Then she had a car accident. In the hospital, they did an MRI scan of her internal organs to make sure nothing was damaged. That’s when they discovered she was full of tumors. The next day they performed emergency surgery on her kidneys, which were being damaged by the growths. Since then she’s had a series of additional operations to remove tumors on the back of her eyes, in her head, all over. She now has a tumor that’s developed on her pancreas. She can’t face having another surgery to remove it, so she’s living with the pain for now.Then Angel Luis, Nitza’s brother, also was in a car accident. Like his sister, scans after the accident revealed that he, too, was as full of tumors. The same sequence followed: emergency kidney surgery, operations to remove brain tumors, and so on. Currently, Angel Luis is undergoing daily radiation therapy for some of his tumors, and he dreads going to the hospital each day for it. His doctors just declared him unable to work for the rest of his life.It turns out Angel Luis and Nitza have a genetic disorder, a rare condition called VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) disease. The tumors are usually benign, but they can turn cancerous and must be removed before they damage healthy tissue. There is no cure yet for this genetic nightmare that’s passed down from generation to generation.Angel Luis Jr. and Mia Lovey have had CAT scans and MRIs. Sadly, they both carry the gene, but VHL doesn’t typically appear until its victims are in their 20’s or 30’s, just as was the case for Angel Luis and Nitza.Jacqueline has been so distraught by what is happening to her family that she’s having difficulty coping and, for the past few months, has not been able to function at her job. Angel drops his son off at the hospital for his radiation treatment every morning on his way to the Museum, and picks him up afterwards. Angel is the only family member who is able to care for the others, and he’s really worried about keeping his job at the Museum with all the responsibilities he has to his family.And the bills keep mounting. Nitza and Mia Lovey live at home with Angel and Jacqueline. Angel Luis, along with his wife and son, still live in their own place, but it’s questionable how long they can continue to do that. Angel Luis hasn’t been able to work since this started, and now he cannot return to his job. Angel is in crisis. His family needs help; yet, he feels reticent to ask. So, we, his friends, are asking for him. Please help Angel take care of his family. Please donate whatever amount you can to help him pay the bills. We can only imagine how the medical expenses are piling up — let alone the cost of supporting his whole family while trying to keep his job at the Museum. If there ever has been a case worthy of our help, this is it.Angel is truly appropriately named; he is a gentle and kind soul who is trying to manage all of this on his own -- without a complaint.  But it’s time for the rest of us to step up and help with their expenses. Please give what you can – right now – they desperately need your help. Please share Angel’s story with everyone you know, and please ask them to give too. Thank you.

Though she be but little, she is fierce.When Bowen was 15 months old, she suffered a massive seizure out of nowhere that eventually led to her diagnosis of a rare brain disorder called Hemimegalencephaly (it took me almost a year to get the pronunciation right). We then learned that one side of her brain developed abnormally and is larger than the other. This abnormality causes intractable epilepsy along with global developmental delay. Bowen is STRONG, fierce and determined. She proved doctor after doctor wrong and met her milestones time after time. She is one of the smartest 3 year olds we know. That being said Hemimegalencephaly is a life long fight. One we are ready to tackle head on. And our path leads us in a different direction for her now. After failing two seizure medicines and having some discouraging test results, doctors at TCH have determined that surgery is the next step for her. In the next few months, she will have what is called a Hemispherectomy . This is one of the most intense surgeries a little girl could go through. They essentially have to disconnect the right side of her brain from the left. She will be in surgery all day and in the hospital for recovery for at least a month afterwards. She is unlikely to regain skills in her left hand (but again our Bowen loves to prove people wrong). She also will take a cut in her vision field which will require intensive therapy to adjust to this new normal.We know now that life from now on will be "before surgery'' and ''after surgery.'' Just as her seizure changed our paths so will this.We sat down with her school and teachers to tell them the news of the Hemispherectomy and immediately her teacher said ''tomorrow we start teaching her how to use her right hand more.'' They came up with ideas on how to make her feel comfortable at a hospital, how they can work as a team to help her in any way they can, and most importantly that they are a shoulder to lean on from here on out.That is what this Go Fund Me is about. Every cent will go to the STARS/STARS Scholarship Program at the Evelyn Rubenstein Jewish Community Center. Bowen will need intensive therapy not only after the surgery but for months and years to come. Every single donation you make will make a difference for not only Bowen but every other child at that school and in this wonderful program. You can see more about STARS here . We had already heard of STARS before she was diagnosed. We immediately fell in love with the program but also decided to tour other special needs schools in the area. We were shocked to find that no one else in Houston has an inclusion program like Bertha Alyce. Preschoolers with disabilities and developmental delays are integrated into a traditional classroom setting where it benefits not only them, but also makes an important impact on their traditional peer groups. What they have here truly is one of a kind and we are extremely lucky.So thank you to each and every one of you who have been there for Bowen and our family. We appreciate you more than you know. Bowen is lucky to have you in her life!

Mara Anthony is the sixth child of Rev Kenneth and Nancy Anthony.  Mara was born sixteen years ago with the congenital heart defect known as Ebstein’s Anomaly.  She is called the Anthony’s miracle baby because she almost died at birth. Mara survived after three weeks in the NICU after birth. After years of medical checkups with her heart specialist, Mara’s condition unfortunately never went away and the family was told she would require surgery to lead a normal lifestyle.      Mara is an outgoing, smart and a beautiful young lady.  Her faith is strong and she is ready to go through this surgery to feel better and go on with her life.  The time has to repair Mara’s heart through open heart surgery.  The procedures that she will undergo are called the “Cone Procedure” where her tricuspid valve will be repaired and the “Glenn Shunt Procedure”.  Although Mara and her family live in Atlanta the surgery will have to take place in Boston on June 14, 2018, their expected stay will be 3-4 weeks for proper post surgical care and recovery.      Needless to say the cost of this medical procedure along with travel, meals, and local transportation will be staggering. Please donate anything you can to help the Anthony’s through this tough time and let's make Mara's dreams come true.

Sometimes life comes at you fast. On April 17th, 2018 Morley was diagnosed with a rare and aggressive cancer, Epithelioid Mesothelioma in the peritoneal (abdomen) and it has been life changing for him and those closest to him.For those who are unfamiliar with Morley’s type of cancer, only 400-500 cases are diagnosed per year. The fact that Morley is only 26 makes his case even more rare as the majority of individuals given this diagnosis are in their 60s and 70s. Treatment requires the expertise of a medical provider not only trained in this specific area of oncology but also apt to treat young people like Morley. Because of this, there are only a handful of such experts in the United States. On Wednesday, May 2nd, Morley will undergo a 10-15-hour surgery in which doctors will begin to remove as much of the cancer as possible. During the surgery, his spleen, gallbladder, appendix and portions of his small and large intestine will be removed. Following surgery, Morley will undergo roughly 18 weeks of chemotherapy. Given Morley’s current inability to work, this go-fund me was created in an effort to ease the cost of medical bills and other accruing expenses. Our hope is that Morley can focus 100% of his effort and energy on beating this cruel and unforgiving disease. Those who know Morley will tell you that he is an incredibly kind-hearted person that truly loves and cares about everyone. He is an amazing son, brother, friend, and husband. Please help us rally behind him with love, prayers, donations, support, and well-wishes – there truly has never been a more deserving person.

My 28 year old daughter, Caroline, was diagnosed with Stage 3 Ovarian Cancer on August 4th, 2018….56 days before her September 29th wedding. She is still planning on having that wedding!  Caroline is a wildlife biologist that lives and works in the state of Wisconsin alongside her sweetheart Ben Olsen, also a wildlife biologist. Ben recently rushed Caroline to a hospital in Green Bay for emergency surgery to relieve what she thought was a severe bowel obstruction. That’s when doctors discovered a large malignant tumor on her left ovary and uterus. Due to the difficulties associated with cancer treatment, we wanted Caroline to be at a cancer center in Atlanta, Georgia, close to our home. Caroline also wanted to go through this with Ben as her husband; so she and Ben rush married at the hospital in Green Bay and made arrangements to start treatment as quickly as possible. As luck would have it, Ben recently started a new job and needs to stay in Wisconsin. He will be doing a lot of traveling back and forth from Green Bay to Atlanta to be with Caroline during her treatments. In order to beat her cancer, Caroline will start with chemotherapy, undergo another surgery then finish with more chemotherapy. Your donations will help fund the treatment costs, travel for Ben, and the post-treatment costs of monitoring and transitioning to life after cancer. Thank you for your love and prayers, and with your help, we will beat this.

column3: Home Health Care for Sean Mach
column9: UPDATE: We are sad to share that Sean passed away on May 28 of a glioblastoma, an aggressive type of brain cancer. He fought a long, difficult battle and tried every treatment available to him - chemotherapies, radiation, and two drug trial treatments. Sean was able to receive excellent home care thanks to all the generous donors. Thank you to all who have supported Sean and his family.Sean and his wife Jessica have two wonderful children (Wyatt, 3, and Zoey, 19 months) and could use a helping hand. Sean is a caring husband, father, and friend with a dry sense of humor. Outside of his family and friends, his loves are Star Wars and the Seahawks. He met his wife Jessica in Pasadena, CA, while working for a subcontractor of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory as an astronautical engineer.  Among many valuable projects he took on during his career, he contributed his talents toward the development of the Mars Curiosity Rover. Sean and Jessica are facing an incredible challenge as he battles brain cancer. We hope to do our part to support them by covering the cost of home health care with this fundraiser. Sean’s JourneyIn July 2016 Sean was diagnosed with glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) and underwent a successful surgery, followed by a year of radiation and chemo. He was doing well until scans indicated he needed another surgery in November 2017. The result of that surgery showed that the tumor had spread, and immunotherapy medication was required. After his round of immunotherapy, he resumed Avastin IV treatments, and he continues to fight hard every day while performing well on neurological tests.Why Help is Needed NowIn April 2018 Sean started experiencing extreme muscle weakness.  He needs help with eating, communication, and mobility. He maintains full comprehension and is choosing to fight by continuing his weekly Avastin IV treatments at University of Washington Medical Center. To ensure Sean receives the care he needs and to keep him safe, his wife Jessica needs to rely on home health care workers 12 hours a day. This care is not covered by insurance.

column3: Help Erin Childs beat brain cancer
column9: In March, Erin experienced a seizure on a typical Sunday at home.   She was rushed to the local hospital and quickly transferred to the excellent care of Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago.  She was diagnosed with a brain tumor.   She had surgery the next day and aprox 45% of the tumor was removed.  After that, she had a course of treatment including daily chemo and radiation.  Erin has faced this treatment with her trademark smile - she is truly beautiful inside and out.These treatments were not curative, so Erin, together with Mom Barb, Dad Dave and fiancee Chris have been tirelessly searching for more options and alternative treatment.  They have travelled to Mayo Clinic in MN and Johns Hopkins in MD.  Two of the foremost brain cancer hospitals in the United States.  At this writing, they are anxiously awaiting input from the team at Johns Hopkins.As you know, the costs incurred for both the travel and the challenge of looking for alternative treatments which may not be covered by insurance are huge.  PLEASE HELP ERIN IN HER BATTLE WITH BRAIN CANCER!!!We will keep you updated on Erin's progress on this page.  For all those that know the Childs family and Erin's fiancee Chris, you know that they are so very loving and always there to support everyone else.  Let's get all of their friends together to support Erin during her illness.  We know her indomitable spirit will prevail.  We love you Erin!

The BSN family establishes this account on Robbie's behalf to assist and support him on his journey of recovery.  On August 2, 2018 Robbie was unable to be reached, he was discovered at his home and had suffered a massive stroke.  Robbie will have a long road of recovery and expense ahead of him as he works toward his recovery.  He is currently unable to move his right side and is in ICU at Plano Presby hospital.  He is surrounded by his family, friends and BSN family as he begins his journey.  The funds raised will help him with meeting the costs of his insurance deductibles, out of pocket maximums, RX's and all other necessary medical costs he will have associated with making a full recovery.

column3: All Hands on Deck for Bronwen
column9: Dear Friends, On December 19, 2017, Bronwen Zwicker learned that she had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS, or Lou Gehrig's disease).  ALS is a disease that affects the nerve cells, or neurons, that control voluntary muscle movement.  Voluntary muscles create movements that include chewing, walking and talking.  The disease disrupts the motor neurons that the brain uses to communicate with the rest of the body, causing them to degenerate and eventually die.  This means that the brain is no longer able to send messages to the muscles.  When the muscles lose function, they become stiff, twitch, weaken, and atrophy. The disease is comprehensive, eventually affecting all voluntary muscles in the body, and inhibiting the affected person's ability to speak, eat, move, and breathe. There is no cure for ALS.  So far, there has been no effective treatment to halt or reverse the progression of the disease.  Three to five years is the amount of time that the majority of people who are diagnosed with ALS have to live.  There are exceptions, with some living ten or more years from when symptoms first appear. ***So far, you have been reading a general overview of ALS.  There are sentences here that skip light years ahead of Bronwen's current everyday experience.  To place commas between words as heavy with meaning as "speak," "eat," "move," and "breathe," as a way of describing all of the vital actions that ALS effectively ends, feels like an insult, a bludgeoning of the nuances that are packed into the very unique experience of being Bronwen Zwicker.  What I am trying to describe is actually impossible to articulate.  I am trying to describe the indescribable.  Bear with me.  I love her, and this hurts.  ***When she was still a child, Bronwen's voice was already so powerful that she was asked to sing lead in a church play.  The congregants who saw her perform thought that she had been hired as a ringer to sing the part.  If you go to the Zwickers' house today and sit on the back porch as the sun is going down, you can still hear that voice, feel it as it reverberates through your entire body and through the lucky air of Richmond, and understand why those congregants thought that they were listening to a trained professional so many years ago.  But singing for Bronwen is more difficult now.  ALS is already affecting the muscles that are required to make those otherworldly sounds.  Something that has always been second nature to Bronwen--such powerful sounds from such a small person!-- has turned into a physical challenge, and it will continue to grow more challenging.  Every day is packed with profound differences from the day before.  There are not enough words to fit on a website that could adequately describe Bronwen Zwicker herself, nor the many changes she has already experienced in the few months since receiving her diagnosis.  What is of utmost importance is to understand that the range of what is needed to facilitate her new everyday--with the realization that this everyday is always changing as the ALS progresses--means that a substantial amount of funding will be needed for Bronwen to be a person living in the United States with ALS.  Given the costs the Zwicker family has already incurred and the unpredictability of the disease itself, there is no entirely accurate way to pinpoint a dollar amount for funds needed.  Safe to say the amount is high, and it will continue to grow higher.  There may be a lot of uncertainty right now, but one thing that is without a doubt is that Bronwen and her family should not have to go broke as a result of ALS.This is where you can help.   Bronwen and her husband, Stephen Martineau, have moved in with Bronwen's parents, Bob and Dianne Zwicker.  They will need to make modifications to their home so that Bronwen can live as comfortably as possible.  Contractors have estimated that the cost for an accessible bathroom alone will be upwards of $30,000.  The modifications are not covered by health insurance. With assistance from friends and family, Bronwen has begun traveling to Baltimore to participate in weekly clinical trials at Johns Hopkins.  Right now she is paying out-of-pocket for travel and overnight lodging.  These costs will continue to add up as she must participate every three weeks in a trial that lasts a total of twenty-four weeks. These are just some of the changes that have happened in four months.  Beyond hospital bills, home modifications, and the costs of traveling for clinical trials, there are myriad expenses that could pile up, but could potentially be covered if enough funds can be raised, including: - technology to help with communication and other activities - a power wheelchair and accessibility ramps - adaptable clothing and footwear - nursing and personal care- complimentary treatments such as massage and acupuncture So let's get this funding going! Spread the word.  Share and re-share.  Any dollar amount will help. Thank you.

Support Mike and Tricia Reling and their Road to RecoveryFor those of you that know and love Mike Reling, Tricia Reling, and all that they bring and do for the community of Gaylord, Michigan and the surrounding areas, it is time to rally and support this couple through their darkest hour.On April 25, 2018 Mike Reling was thirty seconds from going live on air at the Eagle 101.5 when his phone buzzed with a text from his wife of 28 years, Tricia, saying that she had a horrible headache, and something was terribly wrong. Mike rushed home and immediately took Tricia to Otsego Memorial Hospital. Following a CT scan, it was determined that Tricia was suffering a ruptured brain aneurysm and was going to be flown via helicopter to St. Mary’s in Saginaw. Tricia then underwent emergency brain surgery to clamp the brain bleed. This surgery included significant trauma to her skull and brain, of which she will be recovering for an indefinite amount of time. After two weeks in ICU in Saginaw Tricia was released to come home. Despite the joy that step has brought, she remains in a delicate state. One that requires constant around the clock care, numerous medications and expensive co-pays, along with a bumpy road to recovery.Tricia is a self-employed technical writer, whose master of vocabulary, grammar, editing and writing is unparalleled. Yet, today she is having trouble completing a simple text message. She is unable to work and the timetable for her return to writing is completely unknown.Mike has been the voice of Gaylord for more than 21 years, our community’s cheerleader, champion, commentator, and inspirational voice on the Eagle 101.5. He has not been able to work since April 25th, and as Tricia’s sole caregiver his ability to return to work at his regular pace is uncertain. The entire community of Gaylord and surrounding areas have woken daily to his cheerful voice. How many times have we heard Mike help raise money for a local charity, share an inspirational message from a local hero, or have the perfect comment for a tough community moment? Mike is our on-air voice and Tricia is our on-paper gal, and now they are faced with unimaginable bills and medical debt. Coupled with Tricia’s inability to work and significant prescription drug costs weekly, the bills and stressors are mounting.We need to rally to ensure they can remain in our community and in their home. We as a community can work to reduce their financial stresses so that they can focus on Tricia’s recovery and both of their healing from this traumatic event.So, if you know Mike and Tricia Reling, if Tricia ever helped edit your materials, if you have ever heard Mike on the radio, if he ever interviewed you, if you ever laughed at his jokes, if you ever talked baseball with Mike, if you were ever inspired by Mike, his words, or his beams of energy, I humbly ask you to give what you can to support their road to recovery.

column3: Team Elliott: Fighting Like a Girl
column9: Psalm 28:7      The Lord is my strength and my shield;     my heart trusts in him, and he helps me.      My heart leaps for joy,      and with my song I praise him. When Wes and Allie found out they were pregnant with Elliott, they talked about how to pray for her. Undoubtedly, a lot of things came to mind.  But they settled on praying for her to be STRONG and JOYFUL.  And oh my goodness!  STRONG and JOYFUL she is!  At just a few weeks shy of her 2nd birthday, her favorite word (not surprisingly) is NO. This is exactly the fighter spirit she needs to get her through this battle. Thank You, Lord, for answered prayers.On July 11th, after multiple trips to the Urgent Care and Pediatrician, fighting off what was believed to be a virus, Elliott began vomiting blood.  She was rushed from the Emergency Room to MD Anderson Cancer Center via ambulance to confirm the initial diagnosis of a form of Leukemia.  The following day the medical team confirmed her diagnosis as Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia, Type B.      She received her first round of chemotherapy on Friday, July 13th, and will continue intensive inpatient chemotherapy for the next three weeks.  Elliott, along with her Mommy, Daddy, and supporting team, have a long road of treatment ahead.  We would like to raise funds for the family to help with the cost incurred for treatments, hospital stay, meals, etc.  Elliott's Mommy, Allie, is self-employed and does not have the advantage of paid medical leave.  Her Daddy, Wes, is a high School teacher and football coach.  The family is scheduled to close and move into a new house this week.  We would love to ease as many outside burdens as possible so they can remain focused on taking care of sweet Elliott.  Thank you in advance for joining us in becoming a part of Team Elliott.  Your support is invaluable and greatly appreciated.  You can join Team Elliott in “Fighting Like a Girl” in one of three ways:1) PRAY.  We need as many Prayer Warriors on her team as we can get!2) GIVE...as you feel led.3) SHARE...Elliott’s story.    #STRONGANDJOYFUL

Anthony was diagnosed with hydrocephalus April 20th 2018 and was rushed to Denver for emergency surgery to have a shunt placed. Difficulties occurred and he had to undergo a second surgery due to shunt malfunction and is currently in Denver recovering, so he and his parents can return to Albuquerque. Any and all donations are greatly appreciated and all money will go to the parent to help pay for medical cost of the surgery and NICU stay. Thank you.

￼￼￼￼￼￼￼BACKSTORY:  My baby brother Ramses (right) has suffered a lot throughout his young life.  He has been through hip replacement surgery and other health and anxiety problems and always managed to overcome them.  He had been doing great and was enjoying life when suddenly he fell ill and was diagnosed with an advanced stage of Liver disease.   ￼￼￼￼￼￼￼He desperately needs a liver transplant as soon as possible and the medical expenses are incredibly overwhelming. He has no insurance. My family and I are doing everything we can to support him while we try to get him on a liver transplant list that we are told could cost upwards of $45,000 or more.  How you can help Ramses:  Any donation toward saving his life is truly a Godsend.  Even if you cannot donate, prayers and well wishes are very much welcome during this difficult time. Due to Ramses’s fluctuating condition I (Omar Lopez) will be responsible for withdrawing any funds for Ramses which will go directly to him to help cover his medical expenses and the care he needs to survive during this difficult time. Every cent will be used to try and save his life. .........I don't know how you summarize a persons life in one paragraph, much less am I a decent enough writer to truly capture all the wonderful aspects of my brother's personality and all the love I feel he has to offer this world.  He is a kind, quiet, gentle soul.  A fighter who has battled much, and lost much, but always made the best of every situation.  But right now he is scared, and we are desperate for the world's help.  As children we were inseparable, and right now I can't imagine life without my baby brother. Please help us save him.

It all started back in March of 2014 when Gregg noticed his hand was swollen 2x its normal size.  After several doctor appointments over the course of a number of months, he was finally diagnosed with Systemic Scleroderma, something he had never heard of.  For the first year, all it really affected was his hands.  He would get painful ulcerations on his knuckles and they would bleed all the time.  It was very difficult to do anything with is hands and eventually the pain extended to every joint in his body.  It became difficult to walk, work and even sleep.  It was having a terrible effect on his family as they were watching him get worse and worse as each day passed.  Eventually his doctor put him on chemotherapy and he did 18 rounds of Cytoxan.  He suffered like never before.  The nausea hit hard, the pain was unbearable and many times he didn’t think he could finish the treatment.  In addition to the pain and suffering, he wasn't even sure the chemo was working but he kept his faith in the hope that it would slow the Scleroderma down from attacking his internal organs.  He was 2 years into his battle with this awful disease and difficult treatment, but he continued to work as best he could.  With all that was going on, his ability to practice law, earn a living and provide for his family was significantly challenged.  His clients began to notice his tremendous weight loss and loss of energy.  Then his ability to breathe was severely compromised as the Scleroderma began to attack his lungs which were beginning to fail him.  It was shortly thereafter that he had to close the law practice that he spent 14 years building.  It was devastating for him personally, not only because of the loss of income but because the career he had built was being ripped away by a disease he had no control over.  December 18, 2017.  Gregg was reading on his couch at home when his wife, Paula, came in and said he did not look well.  She eventually called her sister, Kim who is an experienced physical therapist.  Kim took his vitals and said if he did not get to a hospital right away he would die.  They called 911 and took him to Lawrence General Hospital and diagnosed him with end stage renal failure and what made it worse…..he could barely breathe, and he really thought he was going to die that night.  Thanks to the help of the medical staff he woke up the next morning!Gregg spent the vast majority of the next 4 months in the hospital and rehab center including Christmas Day and New Year’s. His muscular pain starting to get worse, his body had a difficult time adjusting to dialysis, he suffered from a stroke, and was diagnosed with so many blood clots in his legs he needed surgery.  It was the most painful experience anyone could ever go through and he came very close to losing his left leg from the knee down.  FAST FORWARD TO TODAY.  Gregg needs Oxygen 24/7 to stay alive and the only way to survive or have any type of quality of life is to have a double lung transplant.  None of the Boston hospitals can do the surgery.  UPenn is the only hospital that can do it.  Eventually, he will need to move to Philadelphia because he needs to be within 4 hours of the hospital when he gets the call that they have a set of lungs available for a transplant. Along with the cost of moving to Philly and current medication expenses, the cost of the transplant surgery is 1.6 million dollars.  Most of this is covered by insurance but there will be significant costs he will have to bear.  We are setting up this Go Fund Me Page so friends and family can help raise money to offset some of those significant costs of care for Gregg, and to also to help take care of his family.THANKS FOR READING AND FOR YOUR THOUGHTS, PRAYERS, LOVE AND FINANCIAL SUPPORT.

My name is Rob Coffino, and I am trying to raise money to fund expenses for my kidney transplant. I am a 56 year old father of 2 beautiful children and a husband to a loving wife of 31 years. I have end stage kidney failure, and this transplant will save my life. Upon hearing about my situation,  I am blessed that one of my wife's best friends sister, Dawn immediately began testing to become my donor. Dawn said,  " I  want to see you walk your children down the aisle and live to experience the joy of having grandchildren one day".  Dawn is a completely selfless person, with a heart of gold. She is  sacrificing everything  to help me and my family through this difficult time. I am incredibly blessed that she is in our lives.  After months of endless testing to determine compatability , I am so grateful to announce that as of 9am this morning, WE ARE A MATCH!  We are scheduled for surgery at the Jackson Memorial/University of Miami Hospital on July 30th. Dawn has to relocate to Florida from North Carolina where she currently teaches music to children. She will have to suspend her livelihood  until she has a complete recovery. Unfortunately, I am on disability and the overall expenses will be overwhelming and for these reasons I am with a heavy heart, asking for help from our friends and family. To those of you who are able to donate I am extremely thankful. To those who cannot, I thank you for your thoughts and prayers.I am communicating through Sharyn's Facebook, but would love to hear from you via email @robcoffino@gmail.com
